Rossini's Petite messe solennelle is first performed, by twelve singers, two pianists and a harmonium player in a mansion in Paris.
Gallaudet University is founded in Washington, D.C. , as the first university for the deaf and hard of hearing.
American Civil War : Battle of Fort Pillow – Confederate forces kill most of the African American soldiers who surrender at Fort Pillow, Tennessee .
Choe Je-u , founder of the Donghak Movement, is executed by beheading for sedition, at Daegu , Korea.

Danish-Prussian War ( Second Schleswig War ) – Battle of Dybbøl : The Prussian army, fielding 10,000 men, defeats the Danish defending army of 9,200 at Dybbøl Mill, after an artillery bombardment from April 7 – 18 .
Under terms of the Treaty of London , the United Kingdom voluntarily cedes control of the United States of the Ionian Islands to the Kingdom of Greece .
Société Générale , a major financial group in France , is founded.
American Civil War: The Battle of the Wilderness begins in Spotsylvania County, Virginia .
21 – American Civil War: Battle of Spotsylvania Court House (The Bloody Angle ) – Some 4,000 troops on both sides die in an inconclusive engagement.
Battle of Yellow Tavern – Confederate General J. E. B. Stuart is mortally wounded at Yellow Tavern, Virginia.
Battle of Resaca – The battle begins with Union General Sherman fighting toward Atlanta .
Civil War gold hoax : The New York World and the New York Journal of Commerce publish a fake proclamation that President Abraham Lincoln has issued a draft of 400,000 more soldiers.
The Russian Empire begins the Circassian genocide . More than 1.5 million Circassians are driven from their homeland to the Ottoman Empire , ending the Russo-Circassian War .
Montana Territory is organized out of parts of Washington Territory and Dakota Territory.
Battle of Piedmont – Union forces under General David Hunter defeat a Confederate army at Piedmont, West Virginia , taking nearly 1,000 prisoners.
First Battle of Petersburg
Battle of Cold Harbor – General Ulysses S. Grant pulls his troops from their positions at Cold Harbor, Virginia, and moves south.

Arlington National Cemetery is established in the United States, when 200 acres (0.81 km 2 ) of the grounds of Robert E. Lee's home ( Arlington House ) are officially set aside as a military cemetery , by U.S. Secretary of War Edwin M. Stanton .

American Civil War: Battle of Cherbourg – Confederate States Navy CSS Alabama is sunk in a single-ship action with USS Kearsarge , in the English Channel off the coast of Cherbourg peninsula , France.
New Zealand Wars : The Tauranga Campaign ends.
American Civil War: Battle of Kennesaw Mountain – Confederate troops defeat Union forces near Kennesaw, Georgia .

Dimitri Atanasescu founds the first Romanian school in the Balkans for Aromanians in Trnovo , in the Ottoman Empire (modern-day North Macedonia ). By the early 20th century, the number of these schools will have risen to 106.
The University of Bucharest in Romania is founded.
President Lincoln issues a true proclamation of conscription of 500,000 men, for the U.S. Civil War.

The Third Battle of Nanking climaxes, when the Taiping Heavenly Kingdom capital of Nanking falls to an assault by Imperial Qing dynasty forces, in the last major action of the Taiping Rebellion in China. There are probably more than a million troops in the battle, and the Taiping army sustains at least 100,000 dead.
Battle of Peachtree Creek – Near Atlanta , Confederate forces led by General John Bell Hood unsuccessfully attack Union troops under General William T. Sherman .
Battle of Atlanta – Outside of Atlanta, Confederate General Hood leads an unsuccessful attack on Union troops under General Sherman, on Bald Hill.
Second Battle of Kernstown – Confederate General Jubal Early defeats Union troops led by General George Crook in an effort to keep the Yankees out of the Shenandoah Valley.
Battle of Ezra Church – Confederate troops, led by General Hood, make a third unsuccessful attempt to drive Union forces under General Sherman from Atlanta.
Confederate spy Belle Boyd is arrested by Union troops, and detained at the Old Capitol Prison in Washington, D.C.
Battle of the Crater – Union forces attempt to break Confederate lines, by exploding a large bomb under their trenches.
The Elgin Watch Company is founded in Elgin, Illinois .

American Civil War: Battle of Mobile Bay – At Mobile Bay near Mobile, Alabama , Admiral David Farragut leads a Union flotilla through Confederate defenses, and seals one of the last major Southern ports.
An undeclared Uruguayan War begins, when Uruguay refuses an ultimatum from the Empire of Brazil .
The first fish and chips shop perhaps opens in London.

American Civil War: Battle of Globe Tavern – Forces under Union General Ulysses S. Grant try to cut a vital Confederate supply-line into Petersburg, Virginia , by attacking the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad , forcing the Confederates to use wagons.

The First Geneva Convention , for the Amelioration of the Condition of the Wounded in Armies in the Field, is signed in Geneva by 12 European states, under the auspices of the International Committee for Relief to the Wounded (predecessor of the International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement ).
American Civil War: Union forces, led by General William T. Sherman , launch an assault on Atlanta .
American Civil War: Union forces under General Sherman enter Atlanta, a day after the Confederate defenders fled the city.

6 – Bombardment of Shimonoseki : An American, British, Dutch and French alliance engages the powerful feudal Japanese warlord or daimyō Lord Mōri Takachika , of the Chōshū clan, based in Shimonoseki , Japan.
American Civil War: Atlanta is evacuated on orders of Union General William Tecumseh Sherman.
Pope Pius IX establishes the Diocese of Gozo .
American Civil War: The Second Battle of Cabin Creek is fought in Indian Territory .
The International Workingmen's Association is founded in London.
A calamity is narrowly averted in London at the Erith explosion
American Civil War : First Battle of Saltville – Union forces attack Saltville, Virginia , but are defeated by Confederate troops.
A cyclone kills 70,000 people in and around Calcutta in India.
American Civil War : Battle of Tom's Brook – Union cavalrymen in the Shenandoah Valley defeat Confederate forces at Tom's Brook, Virginia .
The Quebec Conference begins, to discuss plans for the creation of a Dominion of Canada.
Uruguayan War : Forces of the Empire of Brazil invade Uruguay , in support of Venancio Flores ' Colorado Party .

American Civil War : Second Battle of Fair Oaks – Union forces under General Ulysses S. Grant withdraw from Fair Oaks, Virginia , after failing to breach the Confederate defenses around Richmond, Virginia .
Nevada is admitted as the 36th U.S. state .

American Civil War : Battle of Johnsonville – At Johnsonville, Tennessee, troops under the command of Confederate General Nathan Bedford Forrest bombard a Union supply base with artillery, and destroy millions of dollars worth of material.
The capital of Idaho Territory is moved from Lewiston to Boise ; North Idaho declares the move illegal, and proposes secession .
1864 United States presidential election : Abraham Lincoln is reelected, in an overwhelming victory over George B. McClellan .
Hostilities in the Paraguayan War open, with the Paraguayan ship Tacuarí capturing the Brazilian Marquês de Olinda , in the Paraguay River .
Sherman's March to the Sea begins: Union General Sherman burns Atlanta and starts to move south, living off the land, and causing extensive devastation to crops and mills.
The judicial reform of Alexander II is launched in the Russian Empire .
Sherman's March to the Sea – Confederate General John Bell Hood invades Tennessee , in an unsuccessful attempt to draw Union General Sherman from Georgia.
A group of Confederate operatives, calling themselves the Confederate Army of Manhattan , starts fires in more than 20 locations, in an unsuccessful attempt to burn down New York City .

American Indian Wars : Sand Creek massacre – Colorado volunteers, led by Colonel John Chivington , massacre at least 400 Cheyenne and Arapaho noncombatants at Sand Creek, Colorado (where they had been given permission to camp); many of the dead are subsequently mutilated.

American Civil War : Second Battle of Franklin – The Confederate Army of Tennessee , led by General Hood, mounts a dramatically unsuccessful frontal assault on Union positions around Franklin, Tennessee (Hood loses 6 generals and almost a third of his troops).
The Great Fire of Brisbane breaks out in Australia.

American Civil War : Sherman's March to the Sea – At Waynesboro, Georgia , forces under Union General Judson Kilpatrick prevent troops, led by Confederate General Joseph Wheeler , from interfering with Union General Sherman's campaign of destroying a wide swath of the South, on his march to Savannah ; Union forces suffer more than 3 times the casualties as the Confederates, however.
Paraguayan War : Paraguay formally declares war on the Empire of Brazil , in support of the Uruguayan National Party . The war continues to 1870 , with around 300,000 Paraguayan deaths.
16 – American Civil War : Battle of Nashville – Union forces decisively defeat the Confederate Army of Tennessee.
The New York Stock Exchange opens its first permanent headquarters at 10-12 Broad near Wall Street , in New York City.
American Civil War : Second Battle of Fort Fisher – Union forces launch a major amphibious assault against the last seaport held by the Confederates , Fort Fisher , North Carolina .
American Civil War: Union forces capture Fort Fisher.
American Civil War: Hampton Roads Conference : Union and Confederate leaders discuss peace terms.
The municipal administration of Finland is established.
John Deere receives a United States patent for ploughs .
Tennessee adopts a new constitution that abolishes slavery.
The U.S. Congress authorizes formation of the Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen and Abandoned Lands .
Washington College and Jefferson College are merged to form Washington & Jefferson College in the United States.
American Civil War: The Confederate States of America agrees to the use of African American troops.
American Civil War: The Congress of the Confederate States of America adjourns for the last time.
21 – American Civil War : Battle of Bentonville : Union troops compel Confederate forces to retreat from Four Oaks, North Carolina .
American Civil War – Battle of Five Forks : In Petersburg, Virginia , Confederate General Robert E. Lee begins his final offensive.
American Civil War: Confederate President Jefferson Davis and most of his Cabinet flee the Confederate capital of Richmond, Virginia , which is taken by Union troops the next day.
German chemicals producer Badische Anilin- und Sodafabrik ( BASF ) is founded in Mannheim .
American Civil War: Confederate States Army General Robert E. Lee surrenders to Union Army General Ulysses S. Grant at Appomattox Court House , effectively ending the war.

President Lincoln dies early this morning from his gunshot wound, aged 56. Vice President Andrew Johnson becomes the 17th President of the United States upon Lincoln's death and is sworn in later that morning.
Confederate President Jefferson Davis and his entire cabinet arrive in Charlotte, North Carolina , with a contingent of 1,000 soldiers.
German chemicals producer BASF moves its headquarters and factories from Mannheim , to the Hemshof District of Ludwigshafen .
The Treaty of the Triple Alliance of Argentina , Brazil , and Uruguay against Paraguay is formally signed, following the outbreak of the Paraguayan War .

American Civil War: Lieutenant General Richard Taylor , commanding all Confederate forces in Alabama , Mississippi , and eastern Louisiana , surrenders his forces to Union General Edward Canby at Citronelle, Alabama , effectively ending all Confederate resistance east of the Mississippi River.

In the United States: In North Bend, Ohio (a suburb of Cincinnati ), the first train robbery in the country takes place. Jefferson Davis meets with his Confederate Cabinet (14 officials) for the last time, in Washington, Georgia, and the Confederate Government is officially dissolved.
American Civil War: Jefferson Davis is captured by the Union Army near Irwinville, Georgia .
Electric equipment and mobile brand Nokia founded in Tampere , Finland .

13 – American Civil War – Battle of Palmito Ranch : In far south Texas , more than a month after Confederate General Lee 's surrender, the last land battle of the civil war with casualties, ends with a Confederate victory.
Grand Review of the Armies : Union Army troops parade down Pennsylvania Avenue (Washington, D.C.) to celebrate the end of the American Civil War.
Mobile magazine explosion : 300 are killed in Mobile, Alabama , when an ordnance depot explodes.
The Mimosa sets sail with emigrants from Wales for Patagonia .
American Civil War: President of the United States Andrew Johnson issues a proclamation of general amnesty for most citizens of the former Confederacy.
American Civil War: Confederate forces west of the Mississippi River under General Edmund Kirby Smith surrender at Galveston, Texas , under terms negotiated on May 26 , becoming the last to do so.
Richard Wagner 's opera Tristan und Isolde debuts at the Munich Court Theatre .
Battle of the Riachuelo : The Brazilian Navy squadron defeats the Paraguayan Navy.

American Civil War: Union Major General Gordon Granger lands at Galveston, Texas, and informs the people of Texas of the Emancipation Proclamation (an event celebrated in modern times each year as Juneteenth ).
American Civil War: At Fort Towson in Oklahoma Territory , Confederate General Stand Watie , a Cherokee Indian, surrenders the last significant Rebel army.
James Hudson Taylor founds the China Inland Mission at Brighton , England.
Jumbo , a young male African elephant , arrives at London Zoo and becomes a popular attraction.
Lewis Carroll publishes his children's novel Alice's Adventures in Wonderland in England (first trade editions in December).

Following Abraham Lincoln 's assassination on April 14 , the four conspirators condemned to death during the trial are hanged , including David Herold , George Atzerodt , Lewis Powell and Mary Surratt . Her son, John Surratt , escapes execution by fleeing to Canada, and ultimately to Egypt .
First ascent of the Matterhorn : The summit of the Matterhorn in the Alps is reached for the first time, by a party of 7 led by the Englishman Edward Whymper ; 4 die in a fall during the descent.

Wild Bill Hickok – Davis Tutt shootout : In the market square of Springfield, Missouri , Wild Bill Hickok shoots "Little Dave" Davis Tutt dead over a poker debt, in what is regarded as the first true western fast draw showdown.
The SS Great Eastern departs on a voyage to lay a transatlantic telegraph cable .
The New Zealand Parliament first meets in Wellington on a permanent basis, making it de facto the national capital.
The steamer Brother Jonathan sinks off the California coast, killing 225 passengers and crew.
The first narrow gauge mainline railway in the world opens at Grandchester , Australia.
The Dominican Republic regains independence from Spain.
The Shergotty meteorite Mars meteorite falls in Sherghati , Gaya, Bihar in India.
Union Business College (now Peirce College ) is founded in Philadelphia.

Champ Ferguson becomes the first person (and one of only two) to be convicted of war crimes for actions taken during the American Civil War , found guilty by a U.S. Army tribunal on 23 charges, arising from the murder of 53 people. He is hanged on October 20 , two days after the conviction of Henry Wirz for war crimes.
Morant Bay rebellion : Paul Bogle leads hundreds of black men and women in a march in Jamaica ; the rebellion is brutally suppressed by the British governor Edward John Eyre with 400 executed.
Florida drafts its constitution in Tallahassee .
American Civil War : The CSS Shenandoah , last remnant of the Confederate States of America and its military, surrenders in Liverpool after fleeing westward from the Pacific.

Captain Henry Wirz , Confederate superintendent of Andersonville Prison (Camp Sumter) is hanged , becoming the second of two combatants, and only serving regular soldier, to be executed for war crimes committed during the American Civil War .
Duar War between Britain and Bhutan ends with the Treaty of Sinchula, in which Bhutan cedes control of its southern passes to Britain in return for an annual subsidy.
Chincha Islands War : Action of 17 November 1865 – A Spanish gunboat is captured by the Chilean tugboat Independencia off Tomé , in the Bay of Concepción , Chile.
Chincha Islands War: Battle of Papudo – The Spanish ship Covadonga is captured by the Chileans and the Peruvians , north of Valparaíso , Chile.
The United States Congress creates the United States House Committee on Appropriations and the Committee on Banking and Commerce, reducing the tasks of the House Committee on Ways and Means .
Leopold II becomes King of the Belgians, following the death (on December 10) of his father, King Leopold I .

Secretary of State William H. Seward declares the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution ratified by three-quarters of the states, including those in secession. As of December 6 , slavery is legally outlawed in the last two slave states of Kentucky and Delaware, and the remaining 45,000 slaves are freed.
The Kappa Alpha Order is founded at Washington College , Lexington, Virginia .
Jonathan Shank and Barry Ownby form the Ku Klux Klan in the American South , to resist Reconstruction and intimidate carpetbaggers and scalawags , as well as to repress the freedpeople.
Ottoman troops clash with supporters of Maronite leader Youssef Bey Karam , at St. Doumit in Lebanon ; the Ottomans are defeated.
Wesley College, Melbourne , is established.
Volcanic eruption in the Santorini caldera begins.
Battle of Abtao : A Spanish naval squadron fights a combined Peruvian - Chilean fleet, at the island of Abtao, in the Chiloé Archipelago of southern Chile .

The first daylight bank robbery in United States history during peacetime takes place in Liberty, Missouri . This is considered to be the first robbery committed by Jesse James and his gang, although James's role is disputed.
The Calaveras Skull is discovered in California . Purported to be evidence of humans in North America during the Pliocene epoch, it turns out to be a hoax .

The United States Congress overwhelmingly passes the Civil Rights Act of 1866 , the first federal legislation to protect the rights of African-Americans; U.S. President Andrew Johnson vetoes the bill on March 27, and Congress overrides the veto on April 9.
A total lunar eclipse occurs.
Alexander II of Russia narrowly escapes an assassination attempt in the city of St Petersburg .
The kingdoms of Italy and Prussia form an alliance against the Austrian Empire .
The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA) is founded in New York City by Henry Bergh .
Battle of Callao : Peruvian defenders fight the Spanish fleet.
Student Ferdinand Cohen-Blind makes a failed attempt to assassinate Otto von Bismarck in Unter den Linden in Berlin.
London bank Overend, Gurney and Company collapses, precipitating Panic of 1866 .
The United States Congress approves the minting of a nickel 5-cent coin ( nickel ), eliminating its predecessor, the half dime .
Battle of Tuyutí : 32,000 soldiers of the Triple Alliance defeat 24,000 Paraguayan soldiers few miles north of the Paraná, Argentina , in the Paraguayan War , with 16,000 casualties.
First production of the comic opera Cox and Box by F. C. Burnand and Arthur Sullivan at Moray Lodge, Kensington
Bedrich Smetana 's comic opera The Bartered Bride premiered in Prague .
Fenian forces skirmish with Canadian militia at the battles of Ridgeway and Fort Erie .
Calculations indicate Pluto (not known at this time) reaches its only aphelion (furthest point from the Sun ) between 1618 and August 2113.
The Parliament of Canada meets for the first time in Ottawa .
The Agra High Court is established (later shifted to the Allahabad High Court ).
The Austro-Prussian War ("Seven Weeks War") begins when the Austrians and most of the medium-size German states declare war on Prussia.
The Kingdom of Italy declares war on Austria.
In Sweden , the Riksdag of the Estates votes to replace itself by an elected two-chamber Riksdag .
29 – Battle of Langensalza : The Prussians defeat the Hanoverian army.
Battle of Königgrätz : the Prussian army under King Wilhelm and Helmuth von Moltke defeats the Austrian army of Ludwig von Benedek , leading to a decisive Prussian victory in the Austro-Prussian War.
Princess Helena , third daughter of Queen Victoria , marries Prince Christian of Schleswig-Holstein .
Reconstruction Treaty with Choctaw & Chickasaw , completing the abolition of slavery in the United States; see also Choctaw freedmen .
Austro-Prussian War: Naval Battle of Lissa – The Austrian fleet under Wilhelm von Tegetthoff defeats the Italian fleet of Carlo di Persano .
Austro-Prussian War: Battle of Blumenau – Austrians defend Bratislava against the Prussian army, concluding the fighting in the war.
Reconstruction : Tennessee becomes the first U.S. state to be readmitted to the Union following the American Civil War .

The United States Congress passes legislation authorizing the four-star rank of General of the Army (later reestablished as a five-star rank); Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant becomes the first to have this rank.

The SS Great Eastern successfully completes laying the transatlantic telegraph cable between Valentia Island , Ireland, and Heart's Content, Newfoundland , permanently restoring a communications link.
The Metric Act of 1866 becomes law and legalizes the standardization of weights and measures in the United States.
The Treaty of Prague formally ends the Austro-Prussian War . The Duchy of Limburg leaves the German Confederation .
Paraguay successfully defends Curupayty against the Triple Alliance in the Paraguayan War , killing more than 5,000 while sustaining just about 50 casualties.
The Treaty of Vienna ends the war between Austria and Italy; it formalizes the annexation of Venetia by Italy.

French troops under the command of Rear Admiral Pierre-Gustave Roze land at Ganghwa Island , Korea, as part of a punitive expedition against that kingdom for the execution of French Jesuit priests. It is the first military contact between Korea and a Western force.
The office of State President of the South African Republic is created by constitutional amendment approved at a session of the Volksraad .
The Ruse– Varna railway line (the first railway in Bulgaria ) officially opens.
Oaks explosion : The worst mining disaster in England kills 383 miners and rescuers.
The College of Wooster is founded in Ohio .

The Covington–Cincinnati Suspension Bridge opens between Cincinnati, Ohio , and Covington, Kentucky , in the United States, becoming the longest single-span bridge in the world. It was renamed after its designer, John A. Roebling , in 1983 .
African-American men are granted the right to vote in the District of Columbia .
Benito Juárez becomes Mexican president again.
Regent's Park skating disaster in London: 40 people die when ice on a lake breaks.
Emperor Kōmei of Japan dies suddenly, age 36, leaving his son Mutsuhito to succeed him.
Maronite nationalist leader Youssef Bey Karam leaves Lebanon aboard a French ship for Algeria .
The late Emperor Kōmei 's 14-year-old son, Prince Mutsuhito, becomes Emperor Meiji of Japan in a brief ceremony in Kyoto , ending the Late Tokugawa shogunate .
West Virginia University is established in Morgantown .
The Covering of the Senne in Brussels begins.
Augusta Institute is founded in Augusta, Georgia , later known as Morehouse College .

Johann Strauss II 's waltz The Blue Danube ( An der schönen blauen Donau ) is first performed, at a concert of the Vienna Men's Choral Association . Later this year, Strauss will adapt it into its popular purely orchestral version for the Exposition Universelle in Paris.
Battle of Inlon River : The Qing dynasty defeats the Nien rebels in Hubei , China.
The Indiana Daily Student is established at Indiana University in Bloomington.
The United States Congress forbids taxpayer funding of diplomatic envoys to the Holy See (Vatican), begun in 1848 , and breaks off relations . Funding resumes, along with relations, in 1984 .
Nebraska is admitted as the 37th U.S. state .
The Fenian Rising breaks out in Ireland.
An article by Joseph Lister outlining his use of antiseptic surgery is first published in The Lancet .
William III of the Netherlands accepts an offer of 5,000,000 guilders from Napoleon III for the sale of Luxembourg , leading to the Luxembourg Crisis .

The British North America Act receives royal assent, forming the Dominion of Canada, in an event known as the Confederation . This unites the Province of Canada ( Quebec and Ontario ), New Brunswick , and Nova Scotia on July 1 . Ottawa will become the capital.

Alaska Purchase : Alaska is purchased for US$7.2 million from Alexander II of Russia , about 2 cents/acre ($4.19/km 2 ), by United States Secretary of State William H. Seward . Newspapers call this Seward's Folly .
The Strait Settlement of Singapore , formerly ruled from Calcutta , becomes a Crown colony , under the jurisdiction of the Colonial Office in London.
November 3 – Exposition Universelle , an international exhibition in Paris. Among the visitors is Abdülaziz , making the first visit of a Sultan of the Ottoman Empire to Western Europe.

I.C. Sorosis, the first women's fraternity (sorority) founded upon the men's fraternity model, with Pi Beta Phi as its motto, is founded at Monmouth College in Monmouth, Illinois. In 1888 , the motto becomes the name of the organization .
The first political May Day march takes place in Chicago.
Alfred Nobel patents dynamite in the United Kingdom.
Robert William Keate becomes Lieutenant-governor of the Colony of Natal .
The Atlantic Cable Quartz Lode gold mine is named in Montana .
A firing squad executes Emperor Maximilian of Mexico and two of his lieutenants.
The first recorded association football match in Argentina takes place in Buenos Aires .
Queen's Park F.C. , the oldest association football league team in Scotland, is founded.
France declares Cambodia 's independence from Siam ; Cambodia becomes a protectorate of France and Britain.
In Boston , Massachusetts , the Harvard School of Dental Medicine is established as the first dental school in the United States.
The Battle of Fandane-Thiouthioune : The Serer people defeat the Muslim Marabouts of Senegambia .
September 20 – The first Canadian election sees John A. Macdonald 's Conservatives elected to government and Macdonald becomes the Dominion's first prime minister .
Benjamin Disraeli 's Second Reform Act enfranchises many men in cities for the first time, and adds 938,000 to an electorate of 1,057,000 in England and Wales .
Emperor Meiji of Japan marries Empress Shōken (née Masako Ichijō). The Empress consort is thereafter known as Lady Haruko .
The Sheffield Wednesday F.C. is founded, at the Adelphi Hotel in Sheffield .
The first volume of Das Kapital (later translated into English as Capital ) is published by Karl Marx .
The United States takes control of Midway Island .
End of penal transportation from Britain as the last convict ship , the Hougoumont , departs from Portsmouth on an 89-day passage to Western Australia . 62 Fenians are among the transportees.
Alaska is transferred from Russia to the United States, becoming the Department of Alaska .

' Manifest destiny ': Medicine Lodge Treaty – Near Medicine Lodge Creek, Kansas, a landmark treaty is signed by southern Great Plains Indian leaders, requiring Native American Plains tribes to relocate to a reservation in western Oklahoma .
Italian unification : Giuseppe Garibaldi 's troops march into the Papal States .
The first issue of the women's fashion magazine Harper's Bazaar is published. It is issued weekly, but later monthly.
The last shōgun of Japan, Tokugawa Yoshinobu , tenders his resignation to Emperor Meiji .
American temperance crusader Carrie Nation marries Charles Gloyd.
The three ' Manchester Martyrs ' are hanged in England for the murder of a policeman whilst attempting to rescue two Irish Republican Brotherhood members from imprisonment on 18 September.
In a New York City theater, English author Charles Dickens gives his first public reading in the United States.
Beginning of British expedition to Abyssinia .
The Clerkenwell explosion , the most infamous action carried out by the Fenians in Britain in the 19th century.

Angola Horror (Buffalo, New York-area train wreck): The fiery death of 49 people leads John D. Rockefeller to develop and sell his Mineral Seal 300 °F (149 °C) Fire-Tested Burning Oil, and George Westinghouse to invent the railway air brake , which is mandated in the United States in 1893 .
British Expedition to Abyssinia : Robert Napier leads an expedition to free captive British officials and missionaries.

The 15-year-old Mutsuhito, Emperor Meiji of Japan, declares the Meiji Restoration , his own restoration to full power, under the influence of supporters from the Chōshū and Satsuma Domains , and against the supporters of the Tokugawa shogunate , triggering the Boshin War .

Paraguayan War : Brazilian Army commander Luís Alves de Lima e Silva, Duke of Caxias , enters Asunción , Paraguay 's capital. Some days later he declares the war is over. Nevertheless, Francisco Solano López , Paraguay's president, prepares guerrillas to fight in the countryside.
The Arkansas constitutional convention meets in Little Rock .

Penal transportation from Britain to Australia ends, with arrival of the convict ship Hougoumont in Western Australia, after an 89-day voyage from England. There are 62 Fenians among the transportees.
Shōgun Tokugawa Yoshinobu declares the emperor's declaration "illegal", and prepares to attack Kyoto .

31 – Battle of Toba–Fushimi : forces of the Tokugawa shogunate and the allied pro-Imperial forces of the Chōshū, Satsuma and Tosa Domains clash near Fushimi, Kyoto , ending in a decisive victory for the Imperial forces (although in the January 28 naval Battle of Awa , the Shogunate is victorious against Satsuma).
The British War Office sanctions the formation of what becomes the Army Post Office Corps .
In New York City, the Jolly Corks organization is renamed the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks (BPOE).
In the Passage of Humaitá , a Brazilian naval force succeeds in dashing past a Paraguayan fortress on the River Paraguay , considered by some the turning point in the Paraguayan War .
The University of California is founded in Oakland, California , when the Organic Act is signed into California law.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is formed, in New York City .
The Lake Ontario Shore Railroad Company is organized in Oswego, New York .
The Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute is established in Hampton, Virginia .
The Charter Oath , drawn up by his councilors, is promulgated at the enthronement of the Emperor Meiji of Japan, promising deliberative assemblies and an end to feudalism .

Emperor Tewodros II of Ethiopia massacres at least 197 of his own people at Magdala . These are prisoners incarcerated, for the most part, for very trivial offenses, and are killed for requesting bread and water.

13 – Battle of Magdala : A British-Indian task force under Robert Napier inflicts 700 deaths and a crushing defeat on the army of Emperor Tewodros II ; the British and Indians suffer 30 wounded, two of whom subsequently die. Tewodros commits suicide and Magdala is captured, ending the British Expedition to Abyssinia .
July – Fall of Edo : The Japanese city surrenders to Emperor Meiji . Shōgun Tokugawa Yoshinobu submits to the Emperor.
General William Tecumseh Sherman brokers the Treaty of Fort Laramie , between the federal government of the United States and the Plains Indians .
14 – Boshin War – Battle of Utsunomiya Castle , Japan: Forces of the Emperor Meiji resist the retreating troops of the Tokugawa shogunate .
Fenian bomber Michael Barrett becomes the last person publicly hanged in the United Kingdom.
The Parliament of the United Kingdom passes the Capital Punishment Amendment Act , thus ending public hanging.
Memorial Day is observed in the United States for the first time (it was proclaimed on May 5 by General John A. Logan ).
The Treaty of Bosque Redondo is signed, allowing the Navajo to return to their lands in Arizona and New Mexico .
The first Trades Union Congress is held in Manchester , England.
Mihailo Obrenović , Prince of Serbia , is assassinated in Košutnjak , Belgrade .
Fort Fred Steele is established to protect what is at this time the western terminus of the Union Pacific Railway , near modern-day Sinclair, Wyoming .
The cable-operated West Side and Yonkers Patent Railway in Manhattan becomes the first elevated railway in the United States.
Battle of Ueno : Imperial Japanese troops defeat the Shōgitai (elite forces remaining loyal to the shōgun ).
Preacher William Booth establishes the Christian Mission, predecessor of The Salvation Army , in the East End of London .
The Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified.
The Navajo people begin their long march home.
The United States Expatriation Act ("An Act concerning the Rights of American Citizens in foreign States") is adopted.

The Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution is adopted, including the Citizenship Clause and the Equal Protection Clause , legally, if not actually, guaranteeing African Americans full citizenship and equal protection, and all persons in the United States due process of law.

The 8.5–9.0 M w Arica earthquake strikes southern Peru , with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI ( Extreme ), causing 25,000+ deaths and a destructive basin-wide tsunami , that affects Hawaii and New Zealand.

The element later named as helium is first detected in the spectrum of the Sun's chromosphere , by French astronomer Jules Janssen , during a total eclipse in Guntur , British India , but is assumed to be sodium .

Abergele rail disaster in Wales: An Irish Mail passenger train collides with 4 cargo trucks loaded with paraffin oil (more akin to modern kerosine ); 33 are killed (the first major train disaster in Britain).
The Yangzhou riot in China targets a station of the China Inland Mission , and nearly leads to war between Britain and China.
Emperor Meiji of Japan announces that the name of the city of Edo is to be changed to Tokyo.
Tītokowaru's War : Māori leader Tītokowaru defeats a New Zealand military force at Te Ngutu o Te Manu, North Island.
The University of the South holds its first convocation in Sewanee, Tennessee .
Grito de Lares : Rebels (some 400–600 led by Ramón Emeterio Betances ) in the town of Lares declare Puerto Rico independent; the local militia easily defeats them a week later.

Croatian–Hungarian Settlement ( Croatian : Hrvatsko-ugarska nagodba , Hungarian : Horvát–magyar kiegyezés , German : Kroatisch-Ungarischer Ausgleich ) is concluded, governing Croatia's political status in the Hungarian-ruled part of Austria-Hungary until 1918 .
The Opelousas massacre , one of the bloodiest massacres of the Reconstruction era in the United States.
Chulalongkorn starts to rule in Siam .
The City of New York grants Mount Sinai Hospital a 99-year lease for a property on Lexington Avenue and 66th Street , for the sum of $1.00.

Carlos Manuel de Céspedes declares a revolt against Spanish rule in Cuba , in an event known as El Grito de Yara or the Ten Years' War , initiating a war that lasts ten years (Cuba ultimately loses the war at a cost of 400,000 lives and widespread destruction).
The current Japanese era name is changed to the Meiji period . The Edo period ends.
The Uspenski Cathedral , designed by Aleksey Gornostayev , is inaugurated in Helsinki, Finland .
Thomas Edison applies for his first patent, the electric vote recorder.
Time zone : New Zealand officially adopts a standard time, to be observed nationally.
1868 United States presidential election : Republican Ulysses S. Grant defeats Democrat Horatio Seymour .

The Battle of Moturoa, New Zealand, ends in a British defeat, due to an underestimate of Tītokowaru and his fortifications. There are heavy casualties for the colonial army and light casualties for the Māori defenders.

American Indian Wars – Battle of Washita River : In the early morning, United States Army Lieutenant Colonel George Armstrong Custer leads an attack on a band of Cheyenne living on reservation land with Chief Black Kettle , killing 103 Cheyenne.
Paraguayan War – Battle of Ytororó or Itororó: Field-Marshal Luís Alves de Lima e Silva, Duke of Caxias , leads 13,000 Brazilian troops against a Paraguayan fortified position of 5,000 troops.
The world's first traffic signal lights are installed at the junction of Great George Street and Bridge Street in the London Borough of Westminster .
The Greek Presidential Guard is established as the royal escort by King George I .
U.S. President Andrew Johnson grants unconditional pardon to all Civil War rebels.
Abdur Rahman Khan is defeated at Tinah Khan, and exiled from Afghanistan .
Scotland's second oldest professional football team, Kilmarnock F.C. , is founded.
Elizabeth Cady Stanton is the first woman to testify before the United States Congress .
The P.E.O. Sisterhood , a philanthropic educational organization for women, is founded at Iowa Wesleyan College in Mount Pleasant, Iowa .
The Republic of Ezo is proclaimed on the northern Japanese island of Ezo (which will be renamed Hokkaidō on September 20 ) by remaining adherents to the Tokugawa shogunate .
Prospectors in Moliagul, Victoria , Australia, discover the largest alluvial gold nugget ever found, known as the " Welcome Stranger ".
Ranavalona II , the Merina Queen of Madagascar , is baptized.
The Iron and Steel Institute is formed in London.
Mahbub Ali Khan , 2½, begins a 42-year reign as Nizam of Hyderabad .
Tītokowaru's War ends with the surrender of the last Māori troops at large, in the South Taranaki District of New Zealand's North Island .
The American Museum of Natural History is founded in New York.
The State of Morelos is created in Mexico.
10 – Naval Battle of Hakodate : The Imperial Japanese Navy defeats adherents of the Tokugawa shogunate .
Purdue University is founded in West Lafayette, Indiana .

The first transcontinental railroad in North America is completed at Promontory, Utah , by the driving of the " golden spike ". May 10 – The First transcontinental railroad in North America is completed
Women's suffrage : In New York, Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton form the National Woman Suffrage Association .
One day after surrendering at the land Battle of Hakodate (begun 4 December 1868 ), Enomoto Takeaki turns over Goryōkaku to Japanese forces, signaling the collapse of the Republic of Ezo .
Sainsbury's first store, in Drury Lane , London, is opened.
John Wesley Powell departs Green River, Wyoming , with a company of nine other men, on a trip down the Green and Colorado Rivers.
Boston University is chartered by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts .
The Cincinnati Red Stockings open the baseball season as the first fully professional team.
Sherwood College is founded in Nainital , India.
John Wesley Hyatt patents celluloid in Albany, New York .

The fortress of Goryōkaku is turned over to Imperial Japanese forces, bringing an end to the Republic of Ezo , the Battle of Hakodate and the Boshin War , the military phase of the Meiji Restoration .
July 2 – The first Estonian Song Festival takes place in Tartu .
Gävle , Sweden, is destroyed in a city fire; 8,000 people become homeless.
Hippolyte Mège-Mouriès files a patent for margarine in France.
The Irish Church Act 1869 is given royal assent by Queen Victoria , disestablishing the Church of Ireland effective January 1, 1871.
August Bebel and Wilhelm Liebknecht found the Social Democratic Workers' Party of Germany (SDAP).
The University of Oxford wins the first international boat race held on the River Thames , against Harvard University .
Irish scientist Mary Ward is killed by a steam car .
The foundation stone is laid for Neuschwanstein Castle in Bavaria (southern Germany).
Work on the Wallace Monument is completed in Stirling , Scotland.
13 – P&O 's SS Carnatic runs aground and sinks in the Red Sea ; 31 drown.
Black Friday : The James Fisk – Jay Gould Scandal causes a financial panic in the United States.
England's first residential university-level women's college , the College for Women (predecessor of Girton College, Cambridge ), is founded at Hitchin , by Emily Davies and Barbara Bodichon .
The first issue of the scientific journal Nature is published in London, edited by Norman Lockyer .
The first game of American football between two American colleges is played. Rutgers University defeats Princeton University 6–4, in a forerunner to American football and College football .
In Egypt , the Suez Canal , linking the Mediterranean Sea with the Red Sea , is inaugurated in an elaborate ceremony.
The Hudson's Bay Company surrenders its claim to Rupert's Land in Canada, under its letters patent , back to the British Crown .
In Dumbarton , Scotland, the clipper ship Cutty Sark is launched (it is one of the last clippers built, and the only one to survive in the United Kingdom).
American outlaw Jesse James commits his first confirmed bank robbery, in Gallatin, Missouri .
The First Vatican Council opens in Rome.
Paraguayan War : Triple Alliance forces take Asunción .
Construction of the Brooklyn Bridge begins in New York City.
The Musikverein , Vienna, is inaugurated in Austria-Hungary .
John D. Rockefeller incorporates Standard Oil .
A political cartoon for the first time symbolizes the United States Democratic Party with a donkey ( A Live Jackass Kicking a Dead Lion by Thomas Nast for Harper's Weekly ).
Marias Massacre : U.S. soldiers attack a peaceful camp of Piegan Blackfeet Indians, led by chief Heavy Runner.

Reconstruction Era (United States): Virginia rejoins the Union. This year it adopts a new Constitution , drawn up by John Curtiss Underwood , expanding suffrage to all male citizens over 21, including freedmen .
British SS City of Boston departs Halifax, Nova Scotia , on a transatlantic passage on which it will be lost with all 191 aboard.
Goodna State School in Goodna, Queensland , Australia, is founded.
The Fifteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution , guaranteeing African American men the right to vote, is passed.
The U.S. Army Weather Bureau is created within the Army Signal Corps .
Anaheim, California , is incorporated.
Women's suffrage : Women gain the right to vote in Utah Territory .
Military control of Mississippi ends and it is readmitted to the Union.
Hiram Rhodes Revels , a Republican from Mississippi, is sworn into the United States Senate , becoming the first African American to sit in the U.S. Congress .
The Nisshoki 'circle of the sun' flag of Japan is adopted as the national flag for Japanese merchant ships, by proclamation of the Daijō-kan .
The Bulgarian Exarchate is established, by decree of Sultan Abdülaziz of the Ottoman Empire .
Battle of Cerro Corá , Paraguay : Marshal Francisco Solano López 's last troops are cornered by those of the Triple Alliance. López refuses to surrender and is killed, ending the Paraguayan War .
Red River Rebellion : Thomas Scott is executed by Louis Riel 's provisional government, in modern-day Manitoba , Canada.
The first ever international Association football match, England v Scotland , takes place under the auspices of the Football Association at The Oval , London.
Deutsche Bank is founded in Berlin.
Female Infanticide Prevention Act, 1870 , passed in British India by Natalia Fish.
The Ohio Legislature passes the Cannon Act, thereby establishing the Ohio Agriculture and Mechanical College, later Ohio State University .
Thomas Mundy Peterson is the first African American to vote in an election.
A 7.3 earthquake shakes the Chinese county of Batang causing a fire that leaves about 5,000 dead.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City is established.
Antonio Guzmán Blanco begins his first term as President of Venezuela .

The Chicago Base Ball Club, later to be known as the Chicago White Stockings and ultimately the Chicago Cubs , play their first game against the St. Louis Unions of the National Association of Base Ball Players , an amateur league.
The first rugby match is played in New Zealand, between the Nelson Football Club and Nelson College .
The final splice on the first telegraph submarine cable between Great Britain and India is made.
English novelist Charles Dickens dies at Gads Hill Place in Kent , leaving his last book, The Mystery of Edwin Drood , unfinished.

The Tianjin Massacre of 17 foreigners (mostly European Christian priests and nuns) and 40 Chinese people who had converted to Christianity, takes place in China when an angry mob attacks churches established in the city.
The first message by electric telegraph using the Great Britain to India submarine cable is sent from London .
Richard Wagner 's opera Die Walküre is first performed at Munich 's National Theatre .
American President Ulysses S. Grant signs an act making the United States Independence Day , Thanksgiving Day , Christmas Day and New Year's Day federal holidays in the United States.
The Ems Dispatch is published, serving as casus belli for a war between Prussia and France.
Pastor aeternus : Pope Pius IX declares papal infallibility , in matters of faith and morals.
Franco-Prussian War : France declares war on Prussia .
Start of Solar Saros 153 . The final eclipse in this series will be in 3114.
The ' Diggers' Republic ' is proclaimed at Klipdrift in South Africa by diamond miners, with Stafford Parker as president.

The Tower Subway beneath the River Thames in London, the world's first underground passenger "tube" railway, officially opens. Although this lasts as a railway operation only until November, it demonstrates the technologically successful first use of the cylindrical wrought iron tunnelling shield , devised by Peter W. Barlow and James Henry Greathead , and of a permanent tunnel lining of cast iron segments.
The Republic of Ploiești , an uprising against Domnitor Carol of Romania , fails.
The Red River Rebellion in Canada ends with the arrival of the Wolseley Expedition and the flight of Louis Riel .
Franco-Prussian War : Battle of Sedan – Prussian forces defeat the French armies and take Emperor Napoleon III and 100,000 of his soldiers prisoner at Sedan, France .
Emperor Napoleon III of France is deposed and the Third Republic is declared. Empress Eugénie flees to England with her son.
Louisa Swain of Laramie, Wyoming, becomes the first woman in the United States to cast a vote legally since 1807 .
Old Faithful Geyser is observed and named by Henry D. Washburn , during the Washburn–Langford–Doane Expedition to Yellowstone in Wyoming.
Franco-Prussian War : The Siege of Paris (1870–1871) begins. From September 23, balloon mail is sent out of the city.
Capture of Rome ; With Bersaglieri soldiers entering Rome at Porta Pia , the unification of Italy is completed, ending the last remnant of the Papal States and Papal temporal power .
A plebiscite held in Rome supports, by 133,681 votes to 1,507, the annexation of the city by Italy.
Rome becomes the capital of unified Italy .
Léon Gambetta escapes besieged Paris in a hot-air balloon .
The Chinese leaders of June's Tianjin Massacre of foreigners are executed by China's Imperial government.
Franco-Prussian War : Siege of Metz – Marshal François Achille Bazaine , commanding the French left wing, is forced by starvation to surrender the fortifications of Metz .

In the United States, the newly created Weather Bureau (later renamed the National Weather Service ) makes its first official meteorological forecast: "High winds at Chicago and Milwaukee... and along the Lakes".
The Spanish Cortes Generales proclaims Amadeo de Saboya as King Amadeo I of Spain .
Joseph H. Rainey of South Carolina becomes the second black U.S. congressman (following Hiram Rhodes Revels in February).
Juan Prim , prime minister of Spain, is shot by unknown assassins on leaving the Cortes, dying two days later.
Franco-Prussian War : Battle of Bapaume – Prussians win a strategic victory.

Proclamation of the German Empire : The member states of the North German Confederation and the south German states unite into a single nation state , known as the German Empire . The King of Prussia is declared the first German Emperor as Wilhelm I of Germany , in the Hall of Mirrors at the Palace of Versailles . The Constitution of the German Confederation comes into effect. It abolishes all restrictions on Jewish marriage, choice of occupation, place of residence, and property ownership, but exclusion from government employment and discrimination in social relations remain in effect.
Battle of Dijon : Giuseppe Garibaldi 's group of French and Italian volunteer troops, in support of the French Third Republic , win a battle against the Prussians.

1871 French legislative election elects the first legislature of the French Third Republic ; monarchists ( Legitimists and Orleanists ) favourable to peace with the German Empire gain a large majority. The National Assembly meets in Bordeaux .
The United States Commission on Fish and Fisheries is founded.
The District of Columbia Organic Act of 1871 is signed into law by U.S. President Ulysses S. Grant .
The Danish Women's Society is founded to promote women's rights in Denmark; on December 15 it adopts the style Dansk Kvindesamfund .
The first American civil service reform legislation is signed into law by U.S. President Ulysses S. Grant , creating the United States Civil Service Commission .
Mokrani Revolt breaks out in French Algeria against colonial rule.

Origin of the Paris Commune : Troops of the regular French Army , sent by Adolphe Thiers , Chef du pouvoir executive de la République française , to seize cannons stored on the hill of Montmartre , fraternise with civilians and the National Guard , and two army generals are killed. Regular troops are evacuated to Versailles .
The Paris Commune is formally established in France.
The first Rugby Union International results in a 1–0 win, by Scotland over England.
The New Jersey Detective Agency is chartered, and the New Jersey State Detectives are initiated.
In Brooklyn, New York , P. T. Barnum opens his three-ring circus , hailing it as " The Greatest Show on Earth ".
U.S. President Ulysses S. Grant signs the Civil Rights Act of 1871 .
Murder of Jane Clouson , a servant girl, in Eltham , England; her probable murderer is acquitted.
The first supposedly Major League Baseball game is played in America.
The first Major League Baseball home run is hit by Ezra Sutton , of the Cleveland Forest Citys .
The Treaty of Frankfurt is signed, confirming the frontiers between Germany and France. The provinces of Alsace and Lorraine are transferred from France to Germany.
The first trial in the Tichborne case begins, in the London Court of Common Pleas .
French government troops massacre 147 Communards from Belleville, at Père-Lachaise Cemetery in Paris.
Paris Commune falls to French government forces.
Bombardment of the Selee River Forts : Koreans attack two United States Navy warships.

United States expedition to Korea : Captain McLane Tilton leads 109 members of the United States Marine Corps in a punitive naval attack on the Han River forts on Ganghwa Island in Korea, resulting in 250 Koreans dying and diplomatic failure to "open up" Korea.
The Universities Tests Act 1871 removes restrictions which have previously limited access to Oxford , Cambridge and Durham universities to members of the Church of England .
The Meiji government officially adopts the yen as Japan's modern unit of currency. Coins which have been made in advance with the date 1870 are released into circulation.
Trade unions are legalized in the United Kingdom by the Trade Union Act 1871 .
The first cat show is held at the Crystal Palace of London .
August 26 – The first ever photographs of Yellowstone National Park region are taken by photographer William Henry Jackson , during the Hayden Geological Survey of 1871 .
The foundation stone of the first Tay Bridge is laid; the bridge collapses as a train crosses in a storm eight years later.
The Annie becomes the first boat ever launched on Yellowstone Lake , in the Yellowstone National Park region.
Banco de Concepcion, predecessor of Itaú Unibanco , a major financial services provider in South America , is founded in Chile .
One of the few known major hurricanes to strike Hawaii causes significant damage on the islands of Hawaii and Maui .
The abolition of the han system is carried out in Japan.
Adolphe Thiers becomes President of the French Republic.

Whaling disaster of 1871 : The Comet , a brig used by whalers, becomes the first of 33 ships to be crushed in the Arctic ice by an early freeze. Remarkably, all 1,219 people on the abandoned ships are rescued without a single loss of life.

New York City residents, tired of the corruption of the Tammany Hall political machine and "Boss" William M. Tweed , its "Grand Sachem", meet to form the ' Committee of Seventy ' to reform local politics.
West Chester University ( Pennsylvania ) is charted as West Chester Normal School
The Peshtigo fire begins and destroys the town of Peshtigo, Wisconsin , and kills as many as 2,500 people, becoming the deadliest wildfire in United States history.

The Great Chicago Fire breaks out in Chicago, Illinois and burns for 2 days, killing 300 people, destroying 17,500 buildings and leaving 100,000 people homeless. Continental AG is founded as Continental-Caoutchouc und Gutta-Percha Compagnie in Hanover , Germany.
Heinrich Schliemann begins the excavation of Troy .

The Criminal Tribes Act is enacted by the British Raj in India, naming over 160 communities as " Denotified Tribes ", allegedly habitually criminal (it will be repealed in 1949 , after Indian independence).
The Royal Regiment of Artillery forms the first regular Canadian army units, when they create two batteries of garrison artillery, which later become the Royal Canadian Artillery .
Chinese massacre of 1871 . In Los Angeles ' Chinatown , 19 Chinese immigrants are killed by a mob of 500 men.
Liberian President Edward James Roye is deposed in a coup d'état .
Wickenburg Massacre : Six men travelling by stagecoach, in the Arizona Territory , are reportedly murdered by Yavapai people .
The London–Australia telegraph cable is brought ashore at Darwin .

Henry Morton Stanley , Welsh-born correspondent for the New York Herald , locates missing Scottish explorer and missionary Dr. David Livingstone in Ujiji , near Lake Tanganyika , and greets him by saying, "Dr. Livingstone, I presume?" (according to his later account).
German chancellor Otto von Bismarck tries to ban Catholics from the political stage by introducing harsh laws concerning the separation of church and state .
The Deseret Telegraph Company office in Pipe Spring begins service with a message keyed by Ella Stewart . It is the first telegraph sent from Arizona Territory .
The city of Birmingham, Alabama , is incorporated with the merger of three existing towns.
The opera Aida opens in Cairo, Egypt.
Reading F.C. is formed as an Association football club in England.
Thespis , the first of the Gilbert and Sullivan operas, premières in London. It does modestly well, but the two composers will not collaborate again for four years.
Yohannes IV is crowned Emperor of Ethiopia in Axum , the first ruler crowned in that city in over 500 years.
The Cavite mutiny was an uprising of Filipino military personnel of Fort San Felipe , the Spanish arsenal in Cavite , Philippine Islands. : 107
The government of the United Kingdom buys a number of forts on the Gold Coast , from the Netherlands.
A great solar flare , and associated geomagnetic storm , makes northern lights visible as far south as Cuba.
Rex , the most famous parade on Mardi Gras , parades for the first time in New Orleans for Grand Duke Alexei Alexandrovich of Russia .

Filipino priests José Burgos , Mariano Gomez and Jacinto Zamora , collectively known as Gomburza , are executed in Bagumbayan Fields, Manila, Philippines by the authorities of New Spain , on charges of subversion arising from the 1872 Cavite mutiny .
The Metropolitan Museum of Art opens in New York City.
The Prohibition Party holds its first national convention in Columbus, Ohio , nominating James Black as its presidential nominee.
In the United States, Yellowstone National Park (once dubbed "Colter's Hell" after John Colter , of the Lewis and Clark Expedition ) is established as the world's first national park .
The Boston Globe is founded in Boston, Massachusetts , as the largest newspaper of the New England region.
Alfred B. Miller and Elmer Crockett found the South Bend Tribune newspaper in the United States.
Work begins on the Seven Sisters Colliery in South Wales , located on one of the richest coal sources in Britain.
1872 FA Cup Final : In the first ever final of the FA Cup , the world's oldest football competition, Wanderers F.C. defeat Royal Engineers A.F.C. 1–0 at The Oval in Kennington , London.
The 7.4–7.9 M w Lone Pine earthquake shakes eastern California , with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X ( Extreme ); 27 people are killed and 56 injured.
The first Arbor Day is celebrated in Nebraska .
Victoria Woodhull becomes the first woman nominated for President of the United States , although she is a year too young to qualify and does not appear on the ballot.
The Battle of Mañaria , near Bilbao , Spain during the Third Carlist War (1872–1876)

The New Zealand Wars end after 17 years, with the conclusion of Te Kooti's War ; Maori spiritual leader Te Kooti Arikirangi Te Turuk crosses the Waikato River, and enters the territory of the Māori King Tāwhiao , where he is granted asylum.
Trade unions are legalised in Canada.
Thomas Hardy anonymously publishes his novel Under the Greenwood Tree in England.
Hochi Mail News , later Hochi Daily News , a Japanese language newspaper, is first published in Tokyo , although it changes coverage from general news to a sports newspaper from December 1949 .
Mexican President Benito Juarez dies of a heart attack, and Sebastián Lerdo de Tejada becomes interim president.
Explorer William Gosse reaches Uluru in central Australia and names it Ayers Rock.
The Australian Overland Telegraph Line is completed, providing a telegraphic link between Australia and the rest of the world for the first time.
A group of Icaiche Maya under Marcos Canul attack the British garrison at Orange Walk Town in British Honduras .
Shiseido Pharmacy Shop, predecessor of Shiseido , a major worldwide cosmetics brand, is founded in Ginza , Tokyo , Japan.
Upon the death of King Charles XV of Sweden and Norway , he is succeeded as King of both crowns by his brother Oscar II .
The first Shriners Temple (called Mecca) is established in New York City.
University College Wales (later to become Aberystwyth University ) begins its first academic session.
The Mary Celeste sets sail from New York; bound for Genoa, Italy.

Great Boston Fire of 1872 : In Boston , Massachusetts , a large fire begins to burn on Lincoln Street (the 2-day disaster destroys about 65 acres (0.26 km 2 ) of the city, 776 buildings, much of the financial district and causes US$60 million in damage).
U.S. government geologist Clarence King reveals the diamond hoax in Wyoming .
Dresdner Bank is founded in Dresden, Germany .
Claude Monet begins painting Impression, Sunrise ( Impression, soleil levant , the painting that will give a name to Impressionism ) as viewed from his hotel room at Le Havre in France.
The first ever Metropolitan Police strike in London.
"Spitzeder Swindle": Adele Spitzeder 's pioneering Ponzi scheme in Munich collapses.
A meteor shower display of Andromedids is seen over France.

The first international Association football match to be recognised (retrospectively) by FIFA as "official" takes place at Hamilton Crescent , Scotland; the result is Scotland 0-0 England. Earlier international football matches have already taken place in 1870, in 1871 and again in 1872 at the Oval , London.
Assyriologist George Smith presents the first translation of the Epic of Gilgamesh , to a meeting of the Society of Biblical Archaeology in London.
The now-crewless American ship Mary Celeste is found (still seaworthy) by the British brig Dei Gratia in the Atlantic.
In Louisiana , P. B. S. Pinchback becomes the first African-American to govern a U.S. state.
President Ulysses S. Grant establishes the San Carlos Apache Reservation , in southeastern Arizona .
Challenger expedition : HMS Challenger (1858) sails from Portsmouth , England, on the 4-year scientific expedition that lays the foundation for the science of oceanography .
American Indian Wars : Modoc War : First Battle of the Stronghold – Modoc Indians defeat the United States Army .
The Spanish Cortes deposes King Amadeus I , and proclaims the First Spanish Republic .
Censorship : The United States Congress enacts the Comstock Law , making it illegal to send any "obscene, lewd, or lascivious" books through the mail.
The Phi Sigma Kappa student fraternity is founded at the Massachusetts Agricultural College .
Emancipation Day for Puerto Rico : Most slaves are freed.
The Rio Tinto Company is formed in Spain, following the February 17 purchase of the Rio Tinto Mine from the Spanish government by a British investment group.
British ocean liner RMS Atlantic sinks off Nova Scotia , killing 547.
The Kennel Club , the world's first kennel club , is founded in the United Kingdom.
Colfax massacre : More than 60 to 150 black men are murdered in Colfax, Louisiana , while surrendering to a mob of former Confederate soldiers and members of the Ku Klux Klan .
17 – American Indian Wars : The Second Battle of the Stronghold is fought.
In Richmond, Rhode Island , 11 people perish in a train derailment, due to a bridge washout in the village of Richmond Switch (modern-day Wood River Junction ).
Third Carlist War EVENTS IN MADRID, SPAIN -- Brigadier General Carmona confronts the insurgents at the Madrid bullring.
Third Carlist War in Spain: Battle of Eraul – Carlists under General Dorregaray defeat Republicans at Eraul, near Estella.
Classical archaeologist Heinrich Schliemann discovers Priam's Treasure .
American Indian Wars : The Modoc War ends with the capture of Kintpuash ( Captain Jack ).
Alexandra Palace entertainment venue in London is destroyed by fire, only a fortnight after its opening.
Prince Edward Island joins the Canadian Confederation .
New Rush in Griqualand West , South Africa , is renamed Kimberley .

Third Carlist War : Battle of Alpens – Campaigning in Catalonia, a government column under General José Cabrinetty is ambushed at Alpens , 15 miles east of Berga, by Carlist forces under General Francisco Savalls . After heavy fighting, with Cabrinety killed, virtually the entire column of 800 men is killed or captured.
Richard Southey becomes the first Lieutenant-Governor of Griqualand West .
At Adair, Iowa , Jesse James and the James–Younger Gang pull off the first successful train robbery in the American Old West (US$3,000 from the Rock Island Express).
Sir Benjamin Pine becomes Lieutenant-governor of the Colony of Natal .

American Indian Wars : While protecting a railroad survey party in Montana , the Seventh Cavalry , under Lieutenant Colonel George Armstrong Custer , clashes for the first time with the Sioux , near the Tongue River (only 1 man on each side is killed).
A peace treaty is signed between Imperial Russia and the Khanate of Khiva , making the khanate a Russian protectorate.
The Austro-Hungarian North Pole Expedition discovers Franz Josef Land .
The International Meteorological Organization (IMO) is established.
German troops leave France upon completion of payment of indemnity for the Franco-Prussian War .
The Ohio Agricultural and Mechanical College, later Ohio State University , opens its doors with 25 students, including 2 women.
A New York stock market crash helps to trigger the Panic of 1873 , part of the Long Depression .
Classes begin at Drury University in Springfield, Missouri .
Budapest , Hungary's capital, is formed from Pest , Buda and Óbuda .
21 – Irish Home Rule movement : The Home Government Association reconstitutes itself as the Home Rule League .
SS Ville du Havre , on passage from New York to France, collides with Scottish 3-masted iron clipper Loch Earn in mid-Atlantic and sinks in 12 minutes with the loss of 226 lives.
Women of Fredonia, New York , march against the retail liquor dealers in town, to inaugurate the Woman's Crusade of 1873–74.
The Heineken Brewery is founded in Amsterdam , the Netherlands.
French official Francis Garnier is attacked outside Hanoi by Black Flag mercenaries fighting for the Vietnamese .

Third Carlist War : Battle of Bocairente – Campaigning in Valenica, Spanish Republican General Valeriano Weyler is attacked at Bocairente, northwest of Alcoy, by a greatly superior Carlist force under General José Santés. Weyler is initially driven back, losing some of his guns, but in a brilliant counter-attack he turns defeat into victory, and Santés is heavily repulsed and forced to withdraw.
The Woman's Christian Temperance Union is founded, in Hillsboro, Ohio .

Third Carlist War : Siege of Bilbao (until 2 May 1874 ) – Campaigning in Navarre , Pretender Don Carlos VII and General Joaquín Elío besiege Bilbao , held by General Ignacio del Castillo and 1,200 men. The Carlist force is ten times this number, and includes most of the troops from Navarre, Vizcaya and Álava , although a considerable force is left in Guipúzcoa. Despite defeat at nearby Somorrostro, Republican commander Marshal Francisco Serrano , supported by Generals Manuel de la Concha and Arsenio Martínez-Campos , brilliantly breaks the siege, and Concha then marches on Estella.
New York City annexes The Bronx .
Ignacio María González becomes head of state of the Dominican Republic for the first time.

Third Carlist War : Battle of Caspe – Campaigning on the Ebro in Aragon for the Spanish Republican Government, Colonel Eulogio Despujol surprises a Carlist force under Manuel Marco de Bello at Caspe, northeast of Alcañiz. In a brilliant action the Carlists are routed, losing 200 prisoners and 80 horses, while Despujol is promoted to Brigadier and becomes Conde de Caspe.
The Pangkor Treaty (also known as the Pangkor Engagement), by which the British extend their control over first the Sultanate of Perak , and later the other independent Malay States, is signed.

Prince Alfred, Duke of Edinburgh , second son of Queen Victoria , marries Grand Duchess Maria Alexandrovna of Russia , only daughter of Tsar Alexander III of Russia , in the Grand Church of the Winter Palace in Saint Petersburg .
The Oakland Daily Tribune publishes its first issue in California.
Walter Clopton Wingfield patents in Britain a game called "sphairistike", more commonly called lawn tennis .

25 – Third Carlist War : First Battle of Somorrostro – Determined to raise the siege of Bilbao by the Pretender Don Carlos VII, Republican commander Marshal Francisco Serrano sends General Domingo Moriones with a relief force of 14,000 men. Carlists, under General Nicolás Ollo, entrenched at Somorrostro outside Bilbao, drive back a courageous assault by General Fernando Primo de Rivera and then the entire Republican army. The republicans lose 1,200 men, and Moriones loses his nerve, demanding reinforcements and a replacement for himself. Moriones's men entrench and wait.

Third Carlist War : Battle of Castellfollit de la Roca – Appointed to command the Spanish Republican army in the north, General Ramón Nouvilas attempts to relieve the Carlist siege of Olot in Girona. But at Castellfollit de la Roca, in one of the Government's worst defeats, Nouvilas is routed by Carlist General Francesc Savalls , and captured along with about 2,000 of his men. Olot capitulates two days later.
France and Viet Nam sign the Second Treaty of Saigon , further recognizing the full sovereignty of France over Cochinchina .
The Republic of Ecuador is consecrated to the Sacred Heart of Jesus , carried out by President Gabriel García Moreno and supported, blessed and specified by Pope Pius IX .

27 – Third Carlist War : Second Battle of Somorrostro – In a renewed attempt to raise the siege of Bilbao by Don Carlos VII, Republican commander Marshal Francisco Serrano himself arrives with 27,000 men and 70 cannons. However, in three days of fierce fighting, the Carlist General Joaquín Elío, with just 17,000 men, once again drives off the attack at nearby Somorrostro, and it is another six weeks before Serrano manages to relieve Bilbao.

May 15 – A group of young painters, Société Anonyme Coopérative des Artistes, Peintres, Sculpteurs, Graveurs , gives their first exhibition, at the studio of the photographer Nadar in Paris. Louis Leroy 's critical review of it published on 25 April gives rise to the term Impressionism for the movement, with reference to Claude Monet 's Impression, Sunrise .
Third Carlist War : The siege of Bilbao is lifted.
The first commercial horse-drawn carriage debuts in the city of Bombay , plying two routes.
First admission charge at a football game: Harvard beats University of McGill (Montreal) 3–0.
The Mill River dam collapses in Massachusetts , killing 139 people.
Verdi's Requiem is first performed at San Marco in Milan on 22 May 1874, the first anniversary of Manzoni 's death.

Passenger ship British Admiral , on a voyage from Liverpool (England) to Melbourne (Australia), sinks after hitting rocks off King Island (Tasmania) ; only nine of the 88 passengers and crew are rescued.

The first group of Dorsland Trekkers , a series of expeditions by Trekboere in search of political independence and better farming conditions, departs South Africa to settle in Angola , led by Gert Alberts .
Michel Domingue becomes head of state of Haiti .
Andrew Taylor Still starts the movement for osteopathic medicine in the United States at Kirksville, Missouri .

27 – Third Carlist War : Battle of Monte Muro – Carlist forces entrenched around Abárzuza , on the approach to Estella in Navarre , repel an attack by Isabelino/Liberal (supporters of Queen Isabella II) troops led by General Manuel Gutiérrez de la Concha , Marqués del Duero, who is killed on the third day of fighting.
The Chicago Fire of 1874 burns down 47 acres of the city, destroying 812 buildings, killing 20, and resulting in the fire insurance industry demanding municipal reforms from Chicago's city council.

Patrick Francis Healy , S.J., the first Black man to receive a PhD, is inaugurated as president of Georgetown University , the oldest Catholic University in America, and becomes the first Black person to head a predominantly White university.

Third Carlist War : Battle of Oteiza – Two months after Government forces were repulsed from Carlist-held Estella, in Navarre, Republican General Domingo Moriones makes a fresh diversionary attack a few miles to the southeast at Oteiza. In heavy fighting Moriones secures a costly tactical victory over Carlist General Torcuato Mendíri, but the war continues another 18 months, before Estella finally falls.
Captain Lyman's wagon train besieged by Indians in Hemphill County, Texas .

Battle of Liberty Place : In New Orleans , former Confederate Army members of the White League temporarily drive Republican Governor William P. Kellogg from office, replacing him with former Democratic Governor John McEnery . U.S. Army troops restore Kellogg to office five days later.

Texas–Indian wars : U.S. Army Colonel Ranald S. Mackenzie leads his force of 600 men on the successful raid of the last sanctuary of the Kiowa , Comanche and Cheyenne Indian tribes, a village inside the Palo Duro Canyon in Texas, and carries out their removal to the designated Indian reservations in Oklahoma .
The modern University of Zagreb is founded.
The Quebra-Quilos Revolt starts in Paraíba , Empire of Brazil .
The first issue of Japanese-language newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun is published in Tokyo , Japan .
Democrats gain control of the United States House of Representatives for the first time since 1860 .
The University of Adelaide is founded in Australia.
Harper's Weekly publishes a cartoon by Thomas Nast which is the first use of an elephant as a symbol for the Republican Party in the United States.
The New York Zoo hoax , a supposed breakout of animals from the Central Park Zoo , is perpetrated on the public.
John Ernst Worrell Keely demonstrates his "induction resonance motion motor", a perpetual motion machine , which eventually turns out to be a fraud.
The Gamma Phi Beta sorority is founded at Syracuse University . This is the first women's Greek letter organization to be called a sorority .
Premiere of Alfred Cellier 's comic opera The Sultan of Mocha at the Prince's Theatre, Manchester .
Sailing ship Cospatrick carrying emigrants from England bound for New Zealand, catches fire and sinks in the South Atlantic with the loss of all but three of the 472 persons on board.
The United States Greenback Party is established as a political party , made primarily of farmers financially hurt by the Panic of 1873 .
Iceland is granted a constitution and limited home rule from Denmark.
Passage de Vénus is released as the oldest "film" in history.

General Martínez and Brigadier General Luís Daban stage a pronunciamento at Sagunto , and proclaim Isabel's son Alfonso as King of Spain. Subsequently, the Madrid garrison follows suit, and the First Spanish Republic comes to an end.

The Midland Railway of England abolishes the Second Class passenger category, leaving First Class and Third Class. Other British railway companies follow Midland's lead during the rest of the year (Third Class is renamed Second Class in 1956 ).
The Palais Garnier , one of the most famous opera houses in the world, is inaugurated as the home of the Paris Opera.
Guangxu becomes the 11th Qing dynasty Emperor of China at the age of 3. He succeeds his cousin, the Tongzhi Emperor , who had no sons of his own.
The newly proclaimed King Alfonso XII of Spain (Queen Isabella II 's son) arrives in Spain to restore the monarchy during the Third Carlist War .
Camille Saint-Saëns ' orchestral Danse macabre receives its première.

Third Carlist War : Battle of Lácar – Carlist commander Torcuato Mendíri secures a brilliant victory, when he surprises and routs a Government force under General Enrique Bargés at Lácar, east of Estella, nearly capturing newly crowned King Alfonso XII. The Carlists take several pieces of artillery, more than 2,000 rifles, and 300 prisoners. 800 men of both sides are killed (mostly government troops).
The Mason County War begins, as a German-American mob breaks into a prison, and lynches cattle rustlers in central Texas .
The SS Gothenburg sinks off Australia's east coast with the loss of approximately 102 lives, including a number of high-profile civil servants and dignitaries.

The majority of the Yavapai (Wipukyipai) and Tonto Apache (Dil Zhéé) tribes are forced by the United States Cavalry , under command of Brigadier General George Crook , to walk at gunpoint from Arizona 's Verde Valley , to the San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation , 180 miles to the southeast. The two tribes are not allowed to return to the Verde Valley until 1900 .

Newton Booth , 11th Governor of California , resigns, having been elected Senator . Lieutenant Governor of California Romualdo Pacheco becomes acting Governor. He is later replaced by elected governor William Irwin .
The United States Congress passes the Civil Rights Act , which prohibits racial discrimination in public accommodations and jury duty.
Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York John McCloskey is named the first cardinal in the United States.
The Arya Samaj is founded in Mumbai by Swami Dayananda Saraswati .

Ten sophomores from Rutgers College (modern-day Rutgers University) steal a one-ton cannon from the campus of the College of New Jersey (modern-day Princeton University), and start the Rutgers–Princeton Cannon War .
Aristides wins the first Kentucky Derby .
The Metre Convention is signed in Paris, France.
Two American colleges play each other in arguably the first game of college football : Tufts University and Harvard University at Jarvis Field in Cambridge, Massachusetts .
The Dublin whiskey fire in Ireland leaves 13 people dead and causes more than €6 million worth of damage.
The Artisans' and Labourers' Dwellings Improvement Act 1875 is passed in the United Kingdom, to permit slum clearance .
The General Postal Union is established.

7 – Third Carlist War : Battle of Treviño – Advancing on the key city of Vitoria, in Navarre, Spanish Republican commander General Jenardo de Quesada sends General Tello to attack the Carlist lines just to the southwest, at Treviño. The newly appointed Carlist commander General José Pérula is heavily defeated and withdraws, and soon afterwards Quesada enters Vitoria in triumph.
Asia's first stock exchange is established as The Native Share & Stock Brokers Association (the modern-day Bombay Stock Exchange ).
Tanaka Manufacturing, a telecommunications factory in Ginza , Tokyo , a predecessor of Toshiba , a Japanese electromechanics giant , is founded.

Joe Borden throws the first no-hitter in baseball history versus Mike Golden and the Chicago White Stockings in his third start as a replacement for Cherokee Fisher as a member of the Philadelphia White Stockings
Hibernian F.C. is founded by Irishmen in Edinburgh , Scotland.
Captain Matthew Webb becomes the first person to swim the English Channel .
A murder conviction begins to break the power of the violent Irish-American anti-owner coal miners, the " Molly Maguires ", in Pennsylvania.
Battle of Agurdat: An Egyptian invasion of Ethiopia fails, when Emperor Yohannes IV defeats an army led by Werner Munzinger .
Egypt adopts the Gregorian calendar , having previously used the Alexandrian calendar .
The 1864 play Heath Cobblers by Aleksis Kivi is premiered for the first time in Oulu, Finland .
American merchant sailing ship Ellen Southard is wrecked off Liverpool in England; 12 crew and life-boatmen are lost.
Chief Lone Horn of the Minneconjou dies at the Cheyenne River , leaving his son Big Foot as the new chief.
Brigham Young University is founded in Provo, Utah .
The first performance of the Piano Concerto No. 1 by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky is given in Boston , Massachusetts , with Hans von Bülow as soloist.
The Theosophical Society is founded in New York by Helena Blavatsky , Henry Steel Olcott , William Quan Judge , and others.
Blackburn Rovers F.C. is founded in England by two old-boys of Shrewsbury School following a meeting at the Leger Hotel, Blackburn .

American Indian Wars : In Washington, D.C., Indian Inspector E.C. Watkins issues a report stating that hundreds of Sioux and Cheyenne associated with Sitting Bull and Crazy Horse are hostile to the United States (the Battle of the Little Bighorn is fought in Montana the next year).
Battle of Gundat: Ethiopian Emperor Yohannes IV defeats another Egyptian army.
