At least 512 people are killed when a debris hill from the Sumitomo Besshi copper mine at Niihama , Shikoku , Japan, collapses.

After taking over the second-largest city in the Dominican Republic, Santiago de los Caballeros , revolutionists proclaim Horacio Vásquez as the nation's President in rebel-controlled territory. At the same time in the capital at Santo Domingo , president Wenceslao Figuereo steps down after only five weeks in office.
The Olympique de Marseille association football club is founded in France .
General Horacio Vasquez , leader of a revolution against the Dominican Republic 's President Wenceslao Figuereo, arrives at the capital, Santo Domingo and forms a provisional government.

Dreyfus affair : In the retrial of his court-martial, Alfred Dreyfus is again found guilty of treason and sentenced to serve the remaining 10 years of his prison sentence on Devils Island, notwithstanding that the real culprit has previously admitted to his actions.
Northern Arizona University is founded in Flagstaff , as Northern Arizona Normal School.
General Cipriano Castro defeats the Venezuelan Army at the battle of Tocuyito and prepares to march to Caracas to overthrow President Ignacio Andrade .

Preparing for an attack on Britain's Cape Colony from the neighboring Transvaal Republic, Robert Baden-Powell arrives at the border town of Mafeking and begins recruiting volunteers and stockpiling munitions to prepare for an attack and siege .
A Serbian court sentences 30 people convicted for conspiracy to attempt to assassinate the former King Milan , with the two leaders being sentenced to death.
General Manuel Guzman Alvarez of the Venezuelan state of Sucre joins with General Cipriano Castro in a revolt against the Venezuelan government.
Austrian auto designer Ferdinand Porsche attracts worldwide attention when his first car, the Porsche P1 , wins the Berlin Road Race 18 minutes ahead of the second-place finisher.
The Veterans of Foreign Wars (VFW) is founded in the U.S. by Spanish–American War veteran James C. Putnam as the American Veterans of Foreign Service.

The 1899 Ceram earthquake kills 3,864 people on Seram Island , through a tsunami after a 7.8 magnitude earthquake. The villages of Paulohy-Samasuru and Mani, with a combined population of 2,400 people, are swept away by a 29 foot (8.8 m) wave.

Possession of the Mariana Islands is formally transferred from Spain to Germany, which purchased the archipelago (with the exception of Guam ) from Spain for 837,500 German gold marks and become part of German New Guinea .

The boundary dispute between Venezuela and British Guiana is resolved by a binding award from the International Tribunal of Arbitration of five neutral jurists agreed upon by the United Kingdom and the United Venezuelan States.

The South African Republic telegraphs a three-day ultimatum to the U.K., demanding an arbitration of issues and a pullback of troops from the borders between the Republic and the adjoining Cape Colony, Natal and Bechuanaland by October 11.
The French Sudan is divided into two smaller administrative units, Middle Niger (which later becomes the nations of Niger and Gambia) and Upper Senegal (which becomes the nations of Senegal and Mali)
In South Africa, the Second Boer War between the United Kingdom and the Boers of the Transvaal and Orange Free State begins as the Boers invade the British colony of Natal .
The Second Boer War extends into the British Bechuanaland Protectorate (modern-day Botswana ) as the siege of Mafeking begins.
The Boer invasion of the Cape Colony begins with the siege of Kimberley .
French Army officer Ferdinand de Béhagle is put to death by Sudanese warlord Rabih az-Zubayr , prompting a French expedition to be led against Rabih.

The Thousand Days' War begins in Colombia as Colombian Liberal Party soldiers led by General Rafael Uribe Uribe , with support from Venezuela, begin a fight against the government of National Party president Manuel Antonio Sanclemente . The war will continue for 1,130 days.

The Boxer Rebellion begins in China as the Battle of Senluo Temple is fought between more than 4,000 Imperial Chinese Army troops and at least 1,000 rebels from the Society of Righteous and Harmonious Fists .

In the first major clash of the Second Boer War , the Battle of Talana Hill , the British Army drives the Boers from a hilltop position, but with heavy casualties, including their commanding general Sir Penn Symons .

The Battle of Elandslaagte is fought in Natal, as the British Army recaptures the railway station from Boers, then proceeds toward the fortress of Ladysmith . South African General Jan Kock is fatally wounded in the battle and dies 10 days later.

The Battle of Kouno ends after two days in Chad , as French Army Captain Émile Gentil leads a force of 344 troops against a much larger force of Sudanese Arabs, led by the warlord Rabih az-Zubayr . Gentil routs the Sudanese.

The Battle of Ladysmith begins as British troops at the Ladysmith fort attempt to make a preemptive strike against a larger force of South African Republic and Orange Free State troops that is gradually surrounding the fort. After sustaining 400 casualties and having 800 men captured, the British retreat back to the fort where a 118-day siege begins on November 2.

The siege of Ladysmith begins as armies of the two Boer republics cut telegraph lines connecting Ladysmith to the British colony, and try over the next 118 days to starve out the British force. The British defenders will hold the fort without surrendering, until the siege is broken on February 28, 1900 by a force led by Redvers Buller .
The Alpha Sigma Tau sorority is founded in Ypsilanti, Michigan .
The Boers begin the shelling of the British settlement at Mafeking .
The Bronx Zoological Park opens in New York City .
The Boer attack on Ladysmith is repulsed by British artillery, with the Boers sustaining 800 killed and wounded.
The Battle of San Jacinto is fought in the Philippines. The battle demonstrates the limitations to the heavy, wheel-mounted Gatling gun , in uneven territory.
The city of Puerto Cabello in Venezuela surrenders to General Cipriano Castro after heavy fighting.
In Colombia 's Thousand Days' War , the Battle of Bucaramanga ends with a victory of conservative forces over Liberal Party rebels.
The first aerial crossing of the Mediterranean Sea is made by Louis Capazza and Alphonse Fondère in Capazza's balloon.
The American Line 's SS St. Paul becomes the first ocean liner to report her imminent arrival by wireless telegraphy .
Garret Hobart , the incumbent 24th vice president of the United States , dies of cardiovascular disease .
The Battle of Umm Diwaykarat , a decisive British and Egyptian victory, ends the Mahdist War in the Sudan , as the Khalifa of Sudan, Abdallahi ibn Muhammad , is killed.
The FC Barcelona association football club is founded.

The first women to serve, in uniform, in the armed forces of any nation begins service as part of the Canadian Militia Expeditionary Force to Cape Town to serve in the Boer War . Georgina Fane Pope and three other women are enlisted as army nurses.
An explosion kills 32 coal miners at the Carbon Hill mines in Carbonado, Washington .
Second Boer War : Battle of Magersfontein – Boers defeat British forces trying to relieve the Siege of Kimberley .
General French routs Boer troops that had been advancing into the Cape Colony toward Noupoort .
The Association football club A.C. Milan is founded.
The British War Office sends Lord Roberts to South Africa to become the commander of British forces, with Lord Kitchener to be second in command, with 100,000 additional men.
40 coal miners are killed in an explosion near Brownsville, Pennsylvania .
The wreck of the British steamship Ariosto off the coast of Hatteras, North Carolina drowns 21 of the crew.
U.S. Secretary of State John Hay announces the Open Door Policy to promote American trade with China .
Second Boer War : Boers attempt to end the Siege of Ladysmith , which leads to the Battle of Platrand .
Second Boer War : Battle of Spion Kop – Boer troops defeat the British Army .
Boxer Rebellion : Foreign diplomats in Peking , Qing dynasty China, demand that the Boxer rebels (who oppose foreign interests in the country) be disciplined.
Datu Muhammad Salleh, leader of the Mat Salleh Rebellion in North Borneo , is shot dead in Tambunan .
The United Kingdom and the United States sign a treaty for the building of a Central American shipping canal across Central America in Nicaragua .
The International Arbitration Court at The Hague is created, when the Netherlands' Senate ratifies an 1899 peace conference decree.
Second Boer War : British troops defeat the Boers at Ladysmith, South Africa .
Second Boer War : The Siege of Kimberley is lifted.
The Southern Cross expedition led by Carsten Borchgrevink achieves a new Farthest South of 78° 50'S, making the first landing at the Great Ice Barrier .
Second Boer War : Battle of Paardeberg – British troops defeat the Boers.
Two U.S. Navy cruisers are sent to Central America to protect American interests in a dispute between Nicaragua and Costa Rica .
A coal mine explosion in West Virginia , United States, kills 50 miners.
Botanist Hugo de Vries rediscovers Mendel's laws of heredity .
British archaeologist Sir Arthur Evans purchases the land on Crete on which the ruins of the Palace of Knossos stand. He begins to unearth some of the palace three days later.

Karl Landsteiner first reports his discovery of an accurate means for classifying a system of blood type , which will universally be referred to as the ABO blood group system and for which he will be awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1930.
The Exposition Universelle , a world's fair, opens in Paris.
Battle of Kousséri : French forces secure their domination of Chad . Warlord Rabih az-Zubayr is defeated and killed.
Scofield Mine disaster : An explosion of blasting powder in a coal mine in Scofield, Utah , kills 200 people.
The second Olympic Games , Paris 1900 , open (as part of the Paris World Exhibition ).
The United Kingdom proclaims a protectorate over Tonga .
The Chinese province of Manchuria is invaded by the Russian Empire .
Second Boer War : The British annex the Orange Free State , as the Orange River Colony .
Boxer Rebellion : Boxers attack Belgians in the Fengtai railway station.
N'Djamena , the capital city of Chad , is founded as Fort-Lamy by French commander Émile Gentil .
Boxer Rebellion : Peacekeepers from various European countries arrive in China, where they eventually unite with Japanese forces.
Second Boer War : British soldiers take Pretoria .
1899–1900 peasant unrest in Bulgaria starts to turn passive.
The Reichstag approves the second of the German Naval Laws allowing expansion of the Imperial German Navy .
Boxer Rebellion : Battle of Dagu Forts – Naval forces of the Eight-Nation Alliance capture the Taku Forts , on the Hai River estuary in China.
Boxer Rebellion : Boxers gather about 20,000 people near Peking , and kill hundreds of European citizens, including the German ambassador.

Taoist monk Wang Yuanlu discovers the Dunhuang manuscripts , a cache of ancient texts that are of great historical and religious significance, in the Mogao Caves of Dunhuang , China, where they have been sealed since the early 11th century.

Hoboken Docks fire : A wharf fire at the docks in Hoboken, New Jersey , spreads to German passenger ships Saale , Main and Bremen . The fire engulfs the adjacent piers and nearby ships, killing 326 people.
Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria makes a morganatic marriage with Sophie, Duchess of Hohenberg .
The first zeppelin airship flight, by Zeppelin LZ 1 , is carried out over Lake Constance , near Friedrichshafen , Germany .
The Federation of Australia is enacted, marking the unification of its colonies into a single country.
The new German cruise liner SS Deutschland breaks the record for the Blue Riband on her maiden transatlantic voyage with an average speed of 22.4 knots (41.5 km/h).
The first line of the Paris Métro opens.
25 – The First Pan-African Conference is held in London.
King Umberto I of Italy is assassinated by Italian -born anarchist Gaetano Bresci in Monza .
Boxer Rebellion : An international contingent of troops, under British command, invades Peking and frees the European hostages.
The 1900 Galveston hurricane , killing around 8,000 people. It is the deadliest hurricane in U.S. history.
Admiral Fredrik von Otter becomes Prime Minister of Sweden .
Philippine–American War : Battle of Pulang Lupa – Filipino resistance fighters defeat a detachment of American soldiers.
Philippine–American War : Battle of Mabitac – Filipinos under Juan Cailles defeat the Americans.
The Cook Islands become a territory of the United Kingdom.
Max Planck first states Planck's law of black-body radiation to a meeting of the German Physical Society in Berlin, marking the birth of modern quantum mechanics . He restates it on December 14.
1900 United Kingdom general election : voting concludes with the Unionists led by the Marquess of Salisbury re-elected.
The United Kingdom annexes the Transvaal .
1900 United States presidential election : Republican incumbent William McKinley is re-elected by defeating Democratic challenger William Jennings Bryan in a rematch.

1900 Canadian federal election : Liberal incumbent Sir Wilfrid Laurier is reelected by defeating Conservative leader Sir Charles Tupper again after having done that in the 1896 Canadian federal election .
Herbert Kitchener succeeds Frederick Roberts as commander-in-chief of the British forces in South Africa and implements a scorched earth strategy.
The final Anglo-Ashanti War , " War of the Golden Stool ", is declared over. Most of the British troops and Governor James Willcocks depart the city of Kumasi .
History of quantum mechanics : Max Planck presents his groundbreaking paper on quantum theory to the German Physical Society in Berlin .
The German training frigate Gneisenau , with 450 naval cadets on board, sinks in a storm during exercises off of the Spanish coast at Málaga , drowning 136.

The Prix Guzman , first and only prize ever offered for communication with extraterrestrial life , is announced in Paris . A prize of 100,000 francs is provided, except for communication with Mars , which is considered too easy.

Hopetoun Blunder : The first Governor-General of Australia , John Hope, 7th Earl of Hopetoun , appoints Sir William Lyne premier of the new state of New South Wales , but he is unable to persuade other colonial politicians to join his government, and is forced to resign.
Reginald Fessenden makes the first use of amplitude modulation (the basis for AM radio ) for wireless transmission of the human voice, from Cobb Island (Maryland) .
Boxer Rebellion Demands: The foreign powers present their 12 conditions for reform to the Chinese Imperial government, including the payment of a large indemnity.
The first steel produced by electrometallurgy (from an electric furnace) is delivered.
Lord Kitchener reports that Christiaan de Wet has shot one of the "peace" envoys, and flogged two more, who had gone to his commando to ask the Burgher citizens of South Africa to halt fighting.

Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom dies at Osborne House on the Isle of Wight . She is 81 years old and, having ruled for nearly 64 years, will be the second longest-reigning monarch in British history . Her eldest son, Prince Albert Edward, "Bertie", the longest-serving Prince of Wales to this time, succeeds his mother at the age of 59, reigning as King Edward VII , of the United Kingdom and in innovation the British Dominions and also becoming Emperor of India .
Anton Chekhov 's play Three Sisters (Три сeстры, Tri sestry ) is premiered at the Moscow Art Theatre .
The State funeral of Queen Victoria , held at St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle , UK, is attended by many European royals, including Kaiser Wilhelm II and Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria .
Viceroy of India Lord Curzon creates the new North-West Frontier Province in the north of the Punjab region , bordering Afghanistan .
Edward VII opens his first parliament of the United Kingdom .
The Hawaii Territory Legislature convenes for the first time.
The Pacific Mail Steamship Company 's SS City of Rio de Janeiro sinks entering San Francisco Bay , killing 128.
The United Kingdom and Germany agree on the frontier between German East Africa and Nyasaland .
U.S. Steel is incorporated by industrialist J. P. Morgan , as the first billion-dollar corporation.
The Sultan of Turkey orders 50,000 troops to the Bulgarian frontier because of unrest in Macedonia .
The United States Congress passes the Platt Amendment , limiting the autonomy of Cuba as a condition for the withdrawal of American troops.
Irish nationalist demonstrators are ejected by police from the House of Commons of the United Kingdom in London.
In Bremen , an assassination attempt is made on Wilhelm II, German Emperor .
The first large-scale showing of Van Gogh 's paintings takes place in Paris, as 71 are shown at the Bernheim-Jeune gallery, 11 years after his death.
Anti-Semitic rioting breaks out in Budapest .
The Caste War of Yucatán in Mexico officially ends, although Mayan skirmishers continue sporadic fighting for another decade.
The first Australian Parliament opens in Melbourne .
Panic of 1901 : The New York Stock Exchange crashes.
81 miners are killed in an accident at Universal Colliery, Senghenydd in South Wales .
The Club Atlético River Plate is founded in Argentina .
D'Arcy Concession : Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar of Persia grants British businessman William Knox D'Arcy a concession giving him an exclusive right to prospect for oil.
Cuba becomes a United States protectorate .
RMS Lucania is the first Cunard Line ship to receive a wireless radio set.
British peace campaigner Emily Hobhouse reports on the high mortality and cruel conditions in the Second Boer War concentration camps .
The first United Kingdom Fingerprint Bureau is established at Scotland Yard , the Metropolitan Police headquarters in London, by Edward Henry .
The world's first passenger-carrying trolleybus in regular service operates on the Biela Valley Trolleybus route at Königstein , Germany.
Peter O'Connor sets the first International Association of Athletics Federations recognised long jump world record , of 24 ft 11¾ ins (7.61m). The record will stand for 20 years.
Discovery Expedition : Robert Falcon Scott sets sail from Britain on the RRS Discovery to explore the Ross Sea in Antarctica.
The first claimed powered flight is made, by German-born American aviator Gustave Whitehead , in his Number 21 , in Connecticut .
The International Secretariat of National Trade Union Centres is founded in Copenhagen .
Hubert Cecil Booth patents an electric vacuum cleaner , in the United Kingdom.
The National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues (later renamed Minor League Baseball ), is formed in Chicago.
William McKinley assassination : American anarchist Leon Czolgosz shoots U.S. President William McKinley at the Pan-American Exposition in Buffalo, New York . McKinley dies 8 days later.
The Boxer Rebellion in Qing dynasty China officially ends with the signing of the Boxer Protocol .
Vice President Theodore Roosevelt becomes the 26th president of the United States, upon President William McKinley 's death.
Philippine–American War : Balangiga massacre : Filipino guerrillas kill more than forty United States soldiers in a surprise attack in the town of Balangiga .
The British Royal Navy 's first submarine , Holland 1 , is launched at Barrow-in-Furness .
The American yacht Columbia defeats the British Shamrock in the America's Cup yachting race in New York.
Michigan schoolteacher Annie Edson Taylor goes over Niagara Falls in a barrel and survives.
The Sigma Phi Epsilon college fraternity is founded in Richmond, Virginia .
Rachmaninoff 's Piano Concerto No. 2 is premiered in Moscow with the composer playing the solo part.

1901 Caister lifeboat disaster : a life-boat capsizes on service on the east coast of England during a great storm; nine of the twelve crew on board are killed. This gives ride to the lifeboatmen's motto "Never turn back."
The Alpha Sigma Alpha fraternity is founded at Longwood University in Farmville, Virginia .
The Hay–Pauncefote Treaty is signed by the United Kingdom and United States, allowing the U.S. to build the Panama Canal under its sole control.
Auguste Deter is first examined by German psychiatrist Dr. Alois Alzheimer , leading to a diagnosis of the condition that will carry Alzheimer's name .
The first Nobel Prize ceremony is held in Stockholm , on the fifth anniversary of Alfred Nobel 's death.
Guglielmo Marconi receives the first trans-Atlantic radio signal, sent from Poldhu , England, to St. John's , Newfoundland ; it is the letter "S" in Morse code .
The final spike is driven into the Mombasa–Victoria–Uganda Railway , in modern-day Kisumu , Kenya .

A train collision in the New York Central Railroad 's Park Avenue Tunnel kills 17 people, injures 38, and leads to increased demand for electric trains and the banning of steam locomotives in New York City .
Hakkōda Mountains incident : A snowstorm in the Hakkōda Mountains of northern Honshu , Japan , kills 199 during a military training exercise.
The Anglo-Japanese Alliance is signed.
The 1st Conference of the International Woman Suffrage Alliance takes place in Washington, D.C. .
The Berlin U-Bahn underground is opened.
U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt prosecutes the Northern Securities Company for violation of the antitrust Sherman Act .
Australian officers Breaker Morant and Peter Handcock are executed for the murder of Boer prisoners of war near Louis Trichardt .
Second Boer War : Battle of Tweebosch – South African Boers win their last battle over the British Army , with the capture of a British general and 200 of his men.
Jean Sibelius 's Symphony No. 2 is premiered in Helsinki .
The Pattani Sultanate is abolished by the Siamese authority after the last sultan of Pattani refused new administrative reforms by the Siamese.
The Electric Theatre, the first movie theater in the United States, opens in Los Angeles .
Tenor Enrico Caruso makes the first million-selling recording, for the Gramophone Company in Milan .
A new land speed record of 74 mph (119 km/h) is set in Nice , France, by Léon Serpollet driving a steam car.
The 7.5 M w Guatemala earthquake shakes Guatemala with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII ( Severe ), killing between 800 and 2,000.
La Soufrière volcano on the Caribbean island of Saint Vincent erupts, devastating the northern portion of the island and killing 2,000 people
Mount Pelée in Martinique erupts, destroying the town of Saint-Pierre and killing over 30,000.
Alfonso XIII of Spain begins his reign.
Cuba gains independence from the United States.
The White Star Liner SS Ionic is launched by Harland and Wolff in Belfast .
The London School of Economics is opened by Lord Rosebery .
The Treaty of Vereeniging ends the Second Boer War .
Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, predecessor of global consumer goods brand 3M , begins trading as a mining venture at Two Harbors in the United States.
The New York Central Railroad inaugurates the 20th Century Limited passenger train between Chicago and New York City.

The Commonwealth Franchise Act in Australia grants women's suffrage in federal elections for resident British subjects (with certain ethnic minorities excepted), making Australia the first independent country to grant women the vote at a national level, and the first country to allow them to stand for Parliament.
Edward VII institutes the Order of Merit , an order bestowed personally by the British monarch on up to 24 distinguished Empire recipients.
Philippine–American War ends.
Erik Gustaf Boström returns as Prime Minister of Sweden .
The United States Bureau of Reclamation is established within the U.S. Geological Survey .
The Rolling Mill Mine disaster in Johnstown, Pennsylvania , kills 112 miners.
Lord Salisbury retires as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom .
Fluminense Football Club is founded in Rio de Janeiro .
100 miners die in a pit explosion in Wollongong , Australia.
Coronation of Edward VII as King of the United Kingdom and the British Dominions , Emperor of India at Westminster Abbey in London.
A statue of Joan of Arc is unveiled in Saint-Pierre-le-Moûtier , the French town which she stormed in 1429 .
Mount Pelée again erupts in Martinique, destroying the town of Le Morne-Rouge and causing 1,000 deaths.

The first science fiction film , the silent A Trip to the Moon ( Le Voyage dans La Lune ), is premièred at the Théâtre Robert-Houdin in Paris, France, by actor/producer Georges Méliès , and proves an immediate success.
Shiloh Baptist Church stampede : 115 people are killed in a crush at a black church in Birmingham, Alabama , following a mistaken alarm of fire after an address by Booker T. Washington .
The first Borstal (youth offenders' institution) opens in Borstal, Kent , U.K.
A five-month strike by the United Mine Workers in the United States ends.
One of the largest volcanic eruptions of the 20th century occurs at Santa María in Guatemala; over 6,000 people die.
A newspaper cartoon depicting U.S. President "Teddy" Roosevelt refusing to shoot a bear cub inspires creation of the first teddy bear by Morris Michtom in New York City.

On the American frontier , the second-in-command of Butch Cassidy's Wild Bunch , Harvey Logan ("Kid Curry"), is captured after a shootout with lawmen in Knoxville, Tennessee. He is sentenced to a $5,000 fine and 20 years hard labor for robbery but escapes custody in 1903.
The first Aswan Dam on the Nile is completed.
The Commercial Telegraph Agency (TTA, Torgovo-Telegrafnue Agenstvo), predecessor of TASS , is officially established under the Ministry of Finance at Saint Petersburg in the Russian Empire .
Discovery Expedition : British explorers Scott , Shackleton and Wilson reach the furthest southern point reached thus far by man, south of 82°S.
Edward VII is proclaimed Emperor of India .
The Aceh Sultanate was fully annexed by the Dutch forces, deposing the last sultan, marking the end of the Aceh War that have lasted for almost 30 years.
The first west–east transatlantic radio broadcast is made from the United States to England (the first east–west broadcast having been made in 1901 ).

Venezuelan crisis : After agreeing to arbitration in Washington, the United Kingdom, Germany and Italy reach a settlement with Venezuela resulting in the Washington Protocols. The naval blockade that began in 1902 will end.
Cuba leases Guantánamo Bay to the United States "in perpetuity".
In New York City , the Martha Washington Hotel , the first hotel exclusively for women, opens.
The British Admiralty announces plans to build the Rosyth Dockyard as a naval base at Rosyth in Scotland.
The Ottoman Empire and the German Empire sign an agreement to build the Constantinople–Baghdad Railway .
The University of Puerto Rico is founded.
Having abolished the Sokoto Caliphate in West Africa, the new British administration accepts the concession of its last vizier .
The Hay–Herrán Treaty , granting the United States the right to build the Panama Canal , is ratified by the United States Senate . The Colombian senate later rejects the treaty.
The first of a series of auctions of sheep farming land in southern Patagonia takes place impacting established settlers .

21 ( April 6 – 8 O.S. ) – The first Kishinev pogrom , beginning on Easter Day, takes place in Kishinev , capital of the Bessarabia Governorate of the Russian Empire . At least 47 Jews are killed and others injured during mob rioting encouraged by blood libel articles in the press and led by priests; no attempt is made by police or military to intervene until the third day.
Atlético Madrid is officially founded as a professional association football club in Spain .
Leading Macedonian Bulgarian revolutionary Gotse Delchev is killed in a skirmish with the Ottoman army.
The port of Burgas , Bulgaria opens.
The Paris–Madrid race for automobiles begins, during which at least eight people are killed; the French government stops the event at Bordeaux and impounds all of the competitors' cars.
Românul de la Pind , the longest-running newspaper by and about Aromanians until World War II , is founded.
The town of Heppner, Oregon is nearly destroyed by a cloud burst that results in a flash flood that kills about 238 people.
The Ford Motor Company is founded by Henry Ford with $28,000 in cash from 12 investors.

American socialite Aida de Acosta , 19, becomes the first woman to fly a powered aircraft solo when she pilots Santos-Dumont 's motorized dirigible , "No. 9", from Paris to Château de Bagatelle in France.
19 – The first Tour de France bicycle race is held; Maurice Garin wins it.
The British take over the Fulani Empire .
United States Cartridge Company explosion : The explosion of two explosives storage magazines destroys 70 homes, killing 22 residents of Tewksbury, Massachusetts .
August 23 ( July 17 – August 10 , O.S. ) – The Second Congress of the All- Russian Social Democratic Labour Party is held in exile in Brussels , transferring to London.
The Ilinden–Preobrazhenie Uprising , organized by the Secret Macedonian-Adrianople Revolutionary Organization , breaks out in the Ottoman provinces of Macedonia and Adrianople .
The Kruševo Republic is proclaimed in Ottoman Macedonia; it is crushed 10 days later.
Pope Pius X succeeds Pope Leo XIII as the 257th pope .
The Paris Métro train fire at Couronnes results in 84 deaths.
The Judiciary Act is passed in the Australian parliament.
The first stock-car event is held at the Milwaukee Mile .
Joseph Chamberlain resigns as British Colonial Secretary in order to campaign publicly for Imperial Preference .
Grêmio Foot-Ball Porto Alegrense is founded in Porto Alegre , Brazil .
Edmund Barton steps down as Prime Minister of Australia and is succeeded by Alfred Deakin .
The Wreck of the Old 97 Fast Mail train at Stillhouse Trestle, near Danville, Virginia , kills 11 people and inspires a ballad.
Prussia becomes the second jurisdiction to require mandatory driver's licenses for operators of motor vehicles, after New York State in 1901.
13 – First modern World Series : The Boston Americans defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates in eight games.
The High Court of Australia sits for the first time.
The Women's Social and Political Union is founded in the U.K.
Maggie L. Walker becomes the first African American woman to charter a bank.
Separation of Panama from Colombia : With the encouragement of the United States, Panama proclaims itself independent of Colombia .
The English-language South China Morning Post newspaper is first published in Hong Kong .
The United States recognizes the independence of Panama .
The Russian Social Democratic Labour Party splits into two groups: the Bolsheviks (Russian for "majority") and Mensheviks (Russian for "minority").
The Hay–Bunau-Varilla Treaty is signed by the United States and Panama , giving the U.S. exclusive rights over the Panama Canal Zone .
Colorado governor James Hamilton Peabody sends the state militia into the town of Cripple Creek to break up a miners' strike.
SS Petriana is wrecked on a reef outside Melbourne , Australia, causing one of the world's first major oil spills .
The Taj Mahal Palace Hotel in Bombay (now Mumbai ), India opens.
Orville Wright flies an aircraft with a petrol engine , the Wright Flyer , at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina in the first documented and successful powered and controlled heavier-than-air flight.
The Iroquois Theatre fire in Chicago kills 600.
The National Association for Women's Suffrage (Sweden) is founded.
The distress signal CQD is established, only to be replaced 2 years later by SOS .
The Blackstone Library is dedicated, marking the beginning of the Chicago Public Library system.
The Herero Wars in German South West Africa begin.
Anton Chekhov 's last play, The Cherry Orchard («Вишнëвый сад», Vishnevyi sad ), opens at the Moscow Art Theatre directed by Constantin Stanislavski , 6 month's before the author's death.
The Ålesund fire destroys most buildings in the town of Ålesund , Norway, leaving about 10,000 people without shelter.

Halford Mackinder presents a paper on " The Geographical Pivot of History " to the Royal Geographical Society of London in which he formulates the Heartland Theory , originating the study of geopolitics .
The Great Baltimore Fire in Baltimore, Maryland , destroys over 1,500 buildings in 31 hours.
9 – Battle of Port Arthur : A surprise Japanese naval attack on Port Arthur (Lüshun) in Manchuria starts the Russo-Japanese War .
Roger Casement publishes his account of Belgian atrocities in the Congo .

Puccini 's opera Madama Butterfly , with a background theme of Japan–United States relations , debuts at La Scala in Milan , to no great acclaim. On May 28 a revised version opens in Brescia , to huge success.
For $10 million, the United States gains control of the Panama Canal Zone.
The Wisconsin State Capitol , in Madison, Wisconsin , is almost entirely destroyed by fire after a gas jet ignites the newly varnished ceiling.
Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany becomes the first person to make a recording of a political document, using Thomas Edison 's cylinder .
Russo-Japanese War : Russian troops in Korea retreat toward Manchuria , followed by 100,000 Japanese troops.
Scottish National Antarctic Expedition : Led by William Speirs Bruce , the Antarctic region of Coats Land is discovered from the Scotia .
20,000 demonstrators gather in Hyde Park, London , to protest against the importation of Chinese labourers to South African gold mines.
British expedition to Tibet : The Battle of Guru – British troops under Colonel Francis Younghusband defeat ill-equipped Tibetan troops.
1904 Kresna earthquakes : two earthquakes strike near Kresna, Bulgaria, killing at least 200 people.

Joseph F. Smith announces the Second Manifesto in General Conference of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Utah Territory , prohibiting the practice of polygamy , which has continued to be sanctioned by some of its leaders in violation of the 1890 Manifesto officially banning the practice.
10 – Aleister Crowley writes Liber Al vel Legis , better known as The Book of the Law , a text central to Thelema , in Cairo.
The Great Fire of Toronto destroys much of the city's downtown, but there are no fatalities.
The Australian Labor Party becomes the first such party to gain national government, under Chris Watson .
The Louisiana Purchase Exposition World's Fair opens in St. Louis, Missouri (closes December 1 ).
Great Western Railway of England 3700 Class 3440 City of Truro possibly becomes the first railway locomotive to exceed 100 miles per hour (160 km/h).

Russo-Japanese War : Russian minelayer Amur lays a minefield about 15 miles (24 km) off Port Arthur , and sinks Japan 's battleships Hatsuse , 15,000 tons with 496 crew, and Yashima . On the same day, the Japanese protected cruiser Yoshino sinks after being accidentally rammed by the armored cruiser Kasuga , killing over 270 crew, including Captain Sayegi and his second-in-command, Commander Hirowateri. Japan will keep the loss of Yashima secret for over a year.
The International Federation of Association Football, FIFA , is established.
Alpha Gamma Delta , which becomes an international sorority, is founded by 11 women at Syracuse University .
The International Alliance of Women is founded.
A fire aboard the steamboat General Slocum in New York City's East River kills 1,021.
The 1904 Moscow tornado occurs.
The third Modern Olympic Games open in St. Louis, Missouri , United States, as part of the World's Fair .

The first 2,000 of 62,000 contracted Chinese coolies arrive at Durban in South Africa from Qinhuangdao to relieve the shortage of unskilled labourers in the Transvaal Colony gold mines, recruited and shipped by the Chinese Engineering and Mining Corporation (CEMC), of which Herbert Hoover is a director.
A continuous track tractor is patented by David Roberts of Richard Hornsby & Sons of Grantham in England.
British expedition to Tibet : The British expedition under Colonel Francis Younghusband takes Lhasa , Tibet .
Battle of Waterberg : Lothar von Trotha defeats the Herero people in German South West Africa , and drives them into the Omaheke desert, starting the Herero and Namaqua genocide .
Ismael Montes becomes President of Bolivia .
Russo-Japanese War : A Japanese infantry charge fails to take Port Arthur .
Chris Watson resigns as the first Labor Prime Minister of Australia and is succeeded by George Reid ( Free Trade Party ).
Faroese Association football club Klaksvíkar Ítróttarfelag is established.
Griffin Park football ground, home of Brentford F.C. , opens in London.
John Voss sails the rigged dugout canoe Tilikum into the River Thames in England after a 3-year voyage from Victoria, British Columbia , westabout.
British expedition to Tibet : The Dalai Lama signs the Anglo-Tibetan Treaty with Colonel Francis Younghusband .
An early study on the relationship between alcohol and cardiovascular disease is published in the United States.
New Zealand dolphin Pelorus Jack is individually protected by Order in Council under the Sea Fisheries Act.
Phi Delta Epsilon , the international medical fraternity, is founded by Aaron Brown and 8 of his friends, at Cornell University Medical College .
Swedish Association football club IFK Göteborg is founded, becoming the 39th IFK-association .
Alpha Kappa Psi , a co-ed professional business fraternity, is founded on the campus of New York University .
German journalist Anna Rüling , in a speech to the Scientific-Humanitarian Committee in Berlin, makes the first known public statement of the socio-legal problems faced by lesbians .
Loftus Road football stadium opens in London.
Pavlos Melas is encircled at Statista and killed during the Macedonian Struggle .
Theta Tau , a professional engineering fraternity, is founded at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis .
In Germany: The Kaiser-Friedrich-Museum opens in Berlin for the display of fine art. Gustav Mahler 's Symphony No. 5 is premiered by the Gürzenich Orchestra Cologne .
Polytechnic University of the Philippines is founded as Manila Business School, through the superintendence of American C. A. O'Reilley.
Russo-Japanese War : Dogger Bank incident – The Russian Baltic Fleet fires on British trawlers it mistakes for Japanese torpedo boats, in the North Sea .
The first underground line of the New York City Subway opens.
Panama and Uruguay establish diplomatic relations .
1904 United States presidential election : Republican incumbent Theodore Roosevelt defeats Democrat Alton B. Parker .

A continuous track tractor is successfully demonstrated by the Holt Manufacturing Company in the United States. The "caterpillar track" will come to revolutionize construction vehicles and land warfare.
The St. Petersburg Soviet urges a run on the banks ; the attempt fails, and the executive committee is arrested.
Charles Dillon Perrine discovers Jupiter 's largest irregular satellite , later called Himalia , at California's Lick Observatory .
The K.U. or Konservativ Ungdom (Young Conservatives) is founded by Carl F. Herman von Rosen in Denmark.

Theodore Roosevelt announces his "Corollary" to the Monroe Doctrine , stating that the United States will intervene in the Western Hemisphere should Latin American governments prove incapable or unstable.
The Pi Kappa Phi fraternity is founded at the College of Charleston in Charleston, South Carolina.
The East Boston Tunnel opens, for streetcars .
In New York City, the first New Year's Eve celebration is held in Times Square .

In a major defeat in the Russo-Japanese War , Russian General Anatoly Stessel surrenders Port Arthur , located on mainland China, to the Japanese. On January 3, Japan formally repossesses the port, and renames it Ryojun, holding it for the next 40 years. The area will revert in 1945 to China, and become the Lushunkou District .
Baroness Emma Orczy 's play The Scarlet Pimpernel , the forerunner of her novel, opens at the New Theatre in London, beginning a run of 122 performances and numerous revivals.

In the United States: The Lick Observatory announces the discovery on 3 December 1904 of a sixth moon of Jupiter , made by their astronomer Charles D. Perrine . Unlike the first five Jovian satellites discovered, the sixth will be referred to by number as "Jupiter VI" until 1975, when named Himalia . The Senate confirms the nomination of William D. Crum , an African-American, to the office of collector of customs at Charleston, South Carolina after Crum's nomination by President Theodore Roosevelt.

Under the supervision of five editors, work begins on the comprehensive Catholic Encyclopedia , subtitled "An International Work of Reference on the Constitution, Doctrine, Discipline, and History of the Catholic Church" and published by the Robert Appleton Company, specifically set up in New York City for the purpose. The first volume will appear in 1907.
Jens Christian Christensen takes office as the new Prime Minister of Denmark .
A series of three 41 metres (135 ft) high tsunamis kill 61 people in Norway in the villages of Ytre Nesdal and Bødal after a rockslide sweeps down Mount Ramnefjell and crashes into Lake Lovatnet .

In France, Prime Minister Émile Combes and his cabinet announce their resignations after being implicated in the Affair of the Cards ( L'Affaire des Fiches ), a system set up by the War Ministry to purge the French Army officers corps of Jesuits.

The Dominican Republic signs an agreement with the United States to allow the U.S. to administer the collection of customs taxes for Santo Domingo for 50 years, with the U.S. to assume responsibility for payment of the Republic's debts to foreign nations from Dominican income. The agreement is done as an exercise of the " Roosevelt Corollary " to the Monroe Doctrine .
Maurice Rouvier forms a government as the new Prime Minister of France .
Tsar Nicholas II appoints General Dmitri Trepov to be the Governor-General of Saint Petersburg , with absolute power to issue regulations to keep order.

(January 13 O.S. in Russia) Russian Revolution of 1905 : The Imperial Russian Army opens fire on demonstrators in Riga , Governorate of Livonia , killing 73 people and injuring 200. Elections are held in Hungary for the 413 seats in the Országgyűlés , the Kingdom's parliament within Austria-Hungary. Voters overwhelmingly reject the Liberal Party , led by Prime Minister István Tisza , that has ruled Hungary since 1875, and the Liberals lose 118 of their 277 seats, but Emperor Franz Joseph I of Austria-Hungary (in his capacity as King Ferenc József) ignores the results and keeps Tisza in power.
The Nelson Act is passed into law in the United States, providing for racial segregation of schools in the Alaska Territory.
Rioting breaks out in Warsaw , at this time under Russian Imperial rule with a Russian Governor-General.
The U.S. Supreme Court renders its unanimous decision in the landmark case of Swift & Co. v. United States , allowing the federal government to regulate monopolies.

"The greatest ball of the Gilded Age " is held by James Hazen Hyde , the 28-year-old heir to the fortune of the founder of the Equitable Life Assurance Association" at New York City's Sherry Hotel, spending $200,000 for a "Louis XV costume ball" for invited guests.
U.S. Senator John H. Mitchell of Oregon is indicted by a federal grand jury on charges arising from a scandal involving land grants in the state and illegally using his influence for private clients.
The first performance of A Shropshire Lad , the setting to music of the 1896 set of 63 poems of A. E. Housman by Arthur Somervell as a song-cycle , takes place at Aeolian Hall in London .
A simultaneous uprising begins at six cities in Argentina against the government of President Manuel Quintana .

The French ship Anjou is wrecked off of the coast of the uninhabited Auckland Island , located 290 miles (470 km) from the nearest inhabited land in New Zealand . The castaways live on the isle for more than three months until being rescued on May 7.
Eliel Soisalon-Soininen , the Chancellor of Justice of the Grand Duchy of Finland (at this time part of the Russian Empire) is assassinated at Helsingfors (Helsinki).
Prince A. Morrow begins the movement in the U.S. for sex education , with the founding of the Society of Sanitary and Moral Prophylaxis.
The Switzerland national football team plays its first international game, losing to France , 1 to 0.
Six of the 11 crew of the British Royal Navy submarine HMS A5 are killed by a pair of explosions caused by gasoline fumes in port in Ireland.
Grand Duke Sergei Alexandrovich of Russia , the Governor-General of Moscow and uncle of Tsar Nicholas II, is assassinated.
In the Russo-Japanese War , the Battle of Mukden begins in Manchuria .
Sir Wilfrid Laurier introduces a resolution in the Canadian parliament proposing that two new provinces, Alberta and Saskatchewan , be created out of the Northwest Territories.
Rotary International is founded in Chicago in the U.S.
Russia sustains a severe defeat in Manchuria at Tsen-ho-Cheng.
Jane Stanford , the co-founder with her husband Leland of Stanford University , is fatally poisoned while visiting the Moana Hotel in Hawaii.
Russia's Committee of Ministers votes to grant religious freedom to the subjects of the Russian Empire.

Tsar Nicholas II of Russia announces his decision to create an elected assembly, the Duma , to represent the people of the Russian Empire in an advisory capacity, although the real power to make laws will remain with the Tsar and the cabinet of ministers.

Russo-Japanese War : The Japanese capture of Mukden (modern-day Shenyang ) completes the rout of Russian armies in Manchuria . The Russian Army commander, General Aleksey Kuropatkin , telegraphs the Tsar that his armies will be retreating to avoid further danger.
Mata Hari introduces her exotic dance act in the Musée Guimet , Paris.
23 of the 26 crew of the British barque Kyber die when the ship is wrecked off England's Land's End .

Albert Einstein submits his paper "On a heuristic viewpoint concerning the production and transformation of light", in which he explains the photoelectric effect using the notion of light quanta , for publication.
Russia's Committee of Ministers votes to abolish the compulsory use of the Russian language in schools in " Congress Poland " (Tsarstvo Polskoye).
The Theriso revolt begins in Crete as about 1,500 people led by Eleftherios Venizelos demand unification with Greece .
Toastmasters International is founded by Ralph C. Smedley in Bloomington, Illinois .

Jimmy Walsh knocks out Monte Attell, in a controversial six-round bout in Philadelphia, to win recognition of the World Bantamweight Championship by the National Boxing Association, despite being disqualified by the referee.
The British Imperial Penny Post is extended to include Australia.
The Simplon Tunnel through the Alps is opened to railway traffic.
A coal mine explosion at Zeigler, Illinois , kills 50 miners.
In India, the 1905 Kangra earthquake hits the Kangra Valley , kills 20,000 and destroys most buildings in Kangra , McLeod Ganj and Dharamshala .
The body of John Paul Jones , "Father of the American Navy", is located in Paris almost 113 years after his death.
A violent strike by the Teamsters' Union begins in Chicago .
Hundreds of people are killed in Spain in the collapse of a dam holding back a reservoir near Madrid.
Russia 's Tsar Nicholas II issues a decree granting religious freedom to his subjects.
The largest ocean liner in the world at this time, the German SS Amerika is launched.

German General Lothar von Trotha commander of troops in Germany's colony of Südwestafrika (modern-day Namibia ), orders the extermination of the Nama people within the colony's borders, ultimately killing 10,000. Von Trotha's proclamation Aan de oorlogvorende Namastamme , proclaims that "The Nama who chooses not to surrender and lets himself be seen in German territory will be shot, until all are exterminated."

China 's Empress Regent Cixi (Tzu Hsi) abolishes further use in executions of the nation's three most cruel torture execution methods, lingchi ("death by a thousand cuts"), gibbeting (similar to crucifixion , hanging until dying of exposure, thirst or starvation), and desecration of a dying person.
A tornado strikes Laredo, Texas and kills 100.
Albert Einstein completes his doctoral dissertation , A New Determination of Molecular Dimensions (submitted July 30 to the University of Zurich ).
The first world championship of professional wrestling takes place at Madison Square Garden in New York City .
Upon the death of U.S. social activist Ann Reeves Jarvis In West Virginia, her daughter Anna Jarvis resolves to campaign across the United States for a proposed " Mother's Day ".
The 1905 Snyder tornado destroys the town of Snyder, Oklahoma , killing 97.

Albert Einstein submits for publication his paper " Über die von der molekularkinetischen Theorie der Wärme geforderte Bewegung von in ruhenden Flüssigkeiten suspendierten Teilchen " ("On the Motion of Small Particles Suspended in a Stationary Liquid, as Required by the Molecular Kinetic Theory of Heat"), based on his doctoral research, delineating a stochastic model of Brownian motion .
The Natural History Museum, London , unveils its popular exhibit of " Dippy ", an exact replica of the skeleton of the Diplodocus carnegii dinosaur.
Las Vegas , Nevada , is founded when 110 acres (45 ha) of land adjacent to the Union Pacific Railroad tracks are auctioned to form what becomes Downtown Las Vegas .

Abdul Hamid II , the Sultan of the Ottoman Empire establishes the Ullah millet for the Aromanians of the empire. For this reason, the Aromanian National Day is sometimes celebrated on this day. The decision is publicly announced the next day, which is more commonly celebrated.

At the end of two days in fighting in the Battle of Tsushima , the Russian Imperial Navy has suffered the deaths of more than 14,000 of the 18,000 sailors and officers it had brought to the battle, and all but four of its Pacific ships. The Japanese loss is three torpedo boats and 800 men.
Brooklyn Superbas pitcher Elmer Stricklett introduces the " spitball " to major league baseball.
Japan's Prime Minister Katsura Tarō asks U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt to moderate peace discussions to end the Russo-Japanese War .
In Germany 's last royal wedding, Crown Prince Wilhelm , son of Kaiser Wilhelm II and heir to the throne, marries Duchess Cecilie of Mecklenburg-Schwerin in Berlin.
The Norwegian Parliament , the Storting , declares dissolution of the union between Norway and Sweden , giving Norway full independence.
Theodoros Diligiannis , Prime Minister of Greece, is assassinated.
British Princess Margaret of Connaught marries Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden, Duke of Skåne , the future King Gustaf VI Adolf.
Austrian Football Club FC Admira Wacker is founded as SK Admira Wien in Vienna .
A coal mine explosion in Russia kills 500 employees at the Ivan Colliery at Kharsisk.
Ernest Henry Starling introduces the word " hormone " into the English language.
New York Central Railroad 's 20th Century Limited train is derailed in an apparent act of sabotage , killing 21 people.

The Danish Navy training ship Georg Stage is accidentally sunk in port in Copenhagen after English steamship Ancona collides with it, killing 22 teenage recruits. The full-rigger is raised and survives.
" Pomp and Circumstance " is first played as a graduation march, after Yale University music professor Samuel Sanford invited its composer, Sir Edward Elgar , to receive an honorary degree.
The Automobile Association is founded in the United Kingdom.
Albert Einstein submits for publication his paper "On the Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies", establishing his theory of special relativity .
Hundreds of people die in the flooding of guanajunto in Mexico .
France's Chamber of Deputies passes a bill for separation of church and state, 341 to 233.
Alfred Deakin takes office as the new Prime Minister of Australia .
A Japanese expedition takes control of the Russian island of Sakhalin after a short battle.
National Colliery disaster at Wattstown in the Rhondda valley of Wales : an underground explosion kills 120, with just one survivor.
The University of Sheffield is officially opened by King Edward VII in England.
The popular fictional character Arsène Lupin , the gentleman thief, is introduced in France.
Sixty members of the crew of the USS Bennington are killed in an explosion of the U.S. Navy gunboat in the harbor at San Diego .
Florence Kelly deliversher landmark speech about child labor before the convention of the National American Woman Suffrage Association in Philadelphia.
The 1905 Bolnai earthquake (8.4 magnitude) strikes Mongolia , the second-largest on record here.
The Taft–Katsura agreement is reached in Tokyo .
Frankie Neil becomes the new world bantamweight boxing champion by defeating title holder Harry Tenny in a 25-round bout at Colma, California .
At Basel in Switzerland , the International Zionist Conference delegates vote to reject the British offer of land in Uganda for a Jewish homeland.
The Ancient Order of Druids initiates neo-Druidic rituals at Stonehenge in England.
King Oscar II of Sweden appoints Prince Gustaf to serve as his regent.
Fourteen employees of a department store in Albany, New York are killed when the building collapses suddenly.
The peace conference to end the Russo-Japanese War between Russia and Japan begins at Portsmouth, New Hampshire .
The Russian Council appointed by Tsar Nicholas II meets at Peterhoff and approves a plan for a national Duma, the first representative assembly in the Empire.
The first running takes place of the Shelsley Walsh Speed Hill Climb in England, the world's oldest motorsport event to be staged continuously on its original course.
At a referendum in Norway, voters opt almost unanimously for dissolution of the union with Sweden.

Mexican-American prospector Pablo Valencia gets lost in the Sonoran Desert of Arizona with no water. Enduring almost eight days of dehydration, Valencia wanders until he is discovered on August 23 by anthropologist William J. McGee and McGee's Papago Indian assistant, Jose.
Chinese revolutionary leader Sun Yat-sen forms the first chapter of Tongmenghui , a union of all secret societies determined to bringing down the Manchu dynasty .

The Sequoyah Constitutional Convention takes place in Muskogee in the U.S. Indian Territory and approves a constitution for the proposed State of Sequoyah , seeking admission as the only Native American majority state in the U.S. President Roosevelt will reject the idea in favor of joining the Indian Territory with the white-ruled Oklahoma Territory to create the 46th U.S. state.
The sinking of the Japanese ferry Kinjo Maru kills 160 people after the British ship HMS Baralong collides with it in the Sea of Japan.
A. Roy Knabenshue introduces the dirigible to the skies of New York City, piloting the lighter-than-air vehicle within view of hundreds of thousands of spectators.
Frederick D. White becomes the first Commissioner of the Northwest Territories in Canada, and will serve until his death in 1918.
Near Point Barrow, Alaska, the crew of the Norwegian ship Gjoa , led by Roald Amundsen , make the breakthrough of finding the long-sought " Northwest Passage " from the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean.
Tsar Nicholas II issues a decree restoring to Russia's universities the autonomy that had been taken away from them in 1884.
A solar eclipse takes place, with greatest visibility in North Africa.
The Canadian provinces of Alberta and Saskatchewan are established from the southwestern part of the Northwest Territories .
The millennia-old imperial examination system for the civil service is abolished in Qing dynasty China.

Russo-Japanese War : Treaty of Portsmouth – In New Hampshire , a treaty mediated by U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt is signed by Japan and Russia . Russia cedes the island of Sakhalin together with port and rail rights in Manchuria to Japan.
The 7.2 M w Calabria earthquake shakes Southern Italy with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI ( Extreme ), killing between 557 and 2,500 people.
Crystal Palace F.C. is founded in London.
HMS Dreadnought (1906) is laid down in the United Kingdom, revolutionizing battleship design and triggering a naval arms race.
The Wright brothers ' third aeroplane ( Wright Flyer III ) stays in the air for 39 minutes with Wilbur piloting, the first aeroplane flight lasting over half an hour.
The Institute of Musical Art, predecessor of the Juilliard School , opens in New York City .

Annie Kenney and Christabel Pankhurst interrupt a Liberal Party (UK) rally at the Free Trade Hall in Manchester , England, and choose imprisonment when convicted, the first militant action of the suffragette campaign.
The National League's New York Giants win baseball's World Series , beating the American League 's Philadelphia Athletics , 2-0, in Game 5.
The Partition of Bengal is made by Lord Curzon to separate the region of Bengal into Muslim and Hindu territories until its reunification in 1911 .
Lahti , the city of Finland, is granted city rights by Tsar Nicholas II of Russia , the last Grand Duke of Finland.

Russification of Finland : The application of the February Manifesto, removing the veto of the Diet of the autonomous Grand Duchy of Finland over matters considered by the Emperor to concern Russian imperial interests, is interrupted by the new November Manifesto. The Senate of Finland is ordered to put forward a proposal for parliamentary reform, based on unicameralism and universal and equal suffrage .
Lawyer and liberal politician Karl Staaff becomes Prime Minister of Sweden, after a Riksdag election based mainly on voting rights reform.
The Province of Alberta , Canada, holds its first general election .
Norway holds a plebiscite on the monarchy , resulting in popular approval of the Storting 's decision to authorise the government to make the offer of the throne of the newly independent country.
The Japan–Korea Treaty of 1905 ("Eulsa Treaty") effectively makes Korea a protectorate of Japan.
Prince Carl of Denmark becomes King Haakon VII of Norway ; he will reign for 52 years.

28 – The Mataafa Storm buffets the Great Lakes region. Named after the Mataafa , a boat sunk outside of the Duluth Ship Canal , the storm ultimately destroys 29 vessels, leading to 29 deaths and shipping losses of US$3.567 million (1905 dollars).
Irish nationalist Arthur Griffith founds Sinn Féin in Dublin, as a political party whose goal is independence for all of Ireland.
Norsk Hydro , predecessor of Equinor , a state-run energy product and grid brand in Scandinavia , is founded in Norway .
18 – Moscow Uprising : A Bolshevik -led revolt is suppressed by the army.
The 1905 French law on the Separation of the Churches and the State is passed, enacting laïcité .
In support of the Moscow Uprising, the Council of Workers' Deputies of Kiev stages a mass uprising, establishing the Shuliavka Republic in the city, December 12 – 16 .
The Pushkin House is established in Saint Petersburg, Russia, to preserve the cultural heritage of Alexander Pushkin .
In the sport of rugby union , the " Match of the Century " is played between Wales and New Zealand at Cardiff Arms Park .
The Tampere conference , where Vladimir Lenin and Joseph Stalin meet for the first time, is held in Tampere, Finland .

Persian Constitutional Revolution : A nationalistic coalition of merchants, religious leaders and intellectuals in Persia forces the shah Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar to grant a constitution, and establish a national assembly, the Majlis .
April 7 – The Algeciras Conference convenes, to resolve the First Moroccan Crisis between France and Germany .
The SS Valencia strikes a reef off Vancouver Island , Canada, killing over 100 (officially 136) in the ensuing disaster.
The Ecuador–Colombia earthquake (8.8 on the Moment magnitude scale ), and associated tsunami , cause at least 500 deaths.
HMS Dreadnought is launched, sparking a naval race between Britain and Germany .
Native American tribal governments are terminated in Indian Territory , a prerequisite for creating the US state of Oklahoma in 1907 .
Courrières mine disaster : An explosion in a coal mine in France kills 1,060.
In France, Romanian inventor Traian Vuia becomes the first person to achieve an unassisted takeoff in a heavier-than-air powered monoplane , but it is incapable of sustained flight.
The Azusa Street Revival , the primary catalyst for the revival of Pentecostalism this century, opens in Los Angeles .
In the Russian Empire , the Fundamental Laws are announced at the first state Duma .
Karl Staaff steps down as Prime Minister of Sweden over the issue of expanded voting rights. He is replaced by right-wing naval officer and public official Arvid Lindman .
Morral affair : The attempted regicide of Spanish King Alfonso XIII and Queen Victoria Eugenie on their wedding day instead kills 24 bystanders.
Cunard liner RMS Lusitania is launched in Glasgow , as the world's largest ship.
The first Grand Prix in automobile racing is the 1906 French Grand Prix held at Le Mans in France.
The Second Geneva Convention meets.
Alfred Dreyfus is exonerated. He is reinstalled in the French Army on July 21 , thus ending the Dreyfus affair .
In the Grand Duchy of Finland , a new electoral law is ratified, guaranteeing full women's suffrage , the first in modern Europe. Women can also stand in national elections.
The first Imperial German Navy submarine , U-1 , is launched.
1906 Valparaíso earthquake : A magnitude 8.2 earthquake in Valparaíso , Chile leaves approximately 20,000 injured.
Unable to control a rebellion, Cuban President Tomás Estrada Palma requests United States intervention. This leads to the Second Occupation of Cuba , which lasts until 1909 .
Mahatma Gandhi coins the term Satyagraha , to characterize the nonviolence movement in South Africa.
A typhoon and tsunami kill an estimated 10,000 in Hong Kong.
The RMS Mauretania is launched at the River Tyne becoming the world’s largest ship.
The first Gordon Bennett Cup in ballooning is held, starting in Paris. The winning team, piloting the balloon United States , lands in Fylingdales , Yorkshire , England.
The Grand Duchy of Finland becomes the first nation to include the right of women to stand as candidates, when it adopts universal suffrage .
The Majlis of Iran convenes for the first time.
A United States diplomatic crisis with Japan arises, when the San Francisco public school board orders Japanese students to be taught in racially segregated schools ( it is resolved by next year ).
Imposter Wilhelm Voigt impersonates a Prussian officer, and takes over the city hall in Köpenick for a short time.
An aeroplane of Alberto Santos-Dumont takes off at Bagatelle in France, and flies 60 meters (200 feet). This is the first officially recorded powered flight in Europe.
The Union Minière du Haut Katanga , a Belgian mining trust, is created in the Congo .
International Exhibition opens in Christchurch , New Zealand.

SOS becomes adopted internationally as a distress signal (originally for ship-to-shore wireless telegraphy ) on inclusion in the service regulations of the first International Radiotelegraph Convention signed in Berlin and coming into effect on 1 July 1908.
The steamboat Dix sinks en route from Seattle to Port Blakely claiming the lives of approximately 50 passengers and crew.
Russian Prime Minister Pyotr Stolypin introduces agrarian reforms , aimed at creating a large class of land-owning peasants.
Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity forms at Cornell University, Ithaca, New York; it is the first Black Greek-lettered collegiate order of its kind.
The London Underground 's Great Northern, Piccadilly and Brompton Railway opens.
The M w 7.9 1906 Manasi earthquake in Xinjiang, China kills nearly 300 people.
Reginald Fessenden makes the first radio broadcast: a poetry reading, a violin solo, and a speech, from Brant Rock, Massachusetts .
The world's first feature film, The Story of the Kelly Gang , is first shown, at the Melbourne Athenaeum in Australia.
The All-India Muslim League is founded as a political party in Dhaka in the British Raj ; it becomes a driving force for the creation of an independent Pakistan .
1907 Kingston earthquake : A 6.5 M w earthquake in Kingston, Jamaica , kills between 800 and 1,000.
The " Mud March ", the first large procession organised by The National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies ( NUWSS ), takes place in London .
The French warship Jean Bart sinks off the coast of Morocco .
The steamship Larchmont collides with the Harry Hamilton in Long Island Sound ; 183 lives are lost.
SKF , a worldwide mechanical parts manufacturing brand (mainly, bearings and seals ), is founded in Gothenburg , Sweden.
The English mail steamship Berlin is wrecked off the Hook of Holland ; 142 lives are lost.
The Austrian Lloyd steamship Imperatrix , from Trieste to Bombay , is wrecked on Cape of Crete and sinks; 137 lives are lost.
At the opening of the new State Duma in Saint Petersburg , Russia, 40,000 demonstrators are dispersed by Russian troops.
The Prime Minister of Bulgaria , Dimitar Petkov , is assassinated by an anarchist in Sofia .

16 – Elections to the new Parliament of Finland are the first in the world for a national assembly with woman candidates, as well as the first elections in Europe where universal suffrage is applied; 19 women are elected.
The first taxicabs with taximeters begin operating in London.
The first university sports federation in Europe is established in Hungary, with the participation or support of the associations of ten universities and colleges.
Hershey Park opens in Hershey, Pennsylvania .

Al Ahly SC is founded in Cairo by Omar Lotfi, as a gathering place for Egyptian students' unions in the struggle against colonization ; it is the first association football club officially founded in Egypt or Africa .
The 5th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party convenes in secret in London .

Shastri Yagnapurushdas consecrates the murtis of both Sahajanand Swami and Gunatitanand Swami in a single central shrine, thus establishing the Bochasanwasi Shri Akshar Purushottam Swaminarayan Sanstha , later a United Nations affiliate organization.
Persil laundry detergent is first marketed by Henkel of Düsseldorf , Germany, the first to combine bleach with detergent commercially.
August 10 – The Peking to Paris motor race is won by Prince Scipione Borghese , driving a 7-litre 35/45 hp Itala .
The Second Hague Peace Conference opens at The Hague .
The London Underground 's Charing Cross, Euston and Hampstead Railway opens.
Tiflis bank robbery : Bolsheviks attack a cash-filled bank coach in the centre of Tiflis , Georgia , killing 40 people.
The Orange River Colony gains autonomy, as the Orange Free State .
Guardians of the Irish Crown Jewels notice that they have been stolen.
The London Electrobus Company starts running the first ever service of battery-electric buses between London's Victoria Station and Liverpool Street .
The SS Columbia sinks after colliding with the lumber schooner San Pedro , off Shelter Cove, California , resulting in 88 deaths.
The Japan–Korea Treaty of 1907 brings the government and military of the protectorate of Korea more firmly under Japanese control.
31 – The International Anarchist Congress of Amsterdam meets in the Netherlands .
UPS is founded by James E. (Jim) Casey in Seattle, Washington .
The partially completed superstructure of the Quebec Bridge collapses entirely, claiming the lives of 76 workers.
Count Alexander Izvolsky and Sir Arthur Nicolson sign the Anglo-Russian Entente in Saint Petersburg , bringing a pause in The Great Game in Central Asia, and establishing the Triple Entente .
British Cunard Line passenger liner RMS Lusitania sets out on her maiden voyage, from Liverpool (England) to New York City.
Pope Pius X promulgates the encyclical Pascendi Dominici gregis , opposing modernism in the Catholic Church .
Uruguay abolishes capital punishment .
New Zealand and Newfoundland become dominions of the British Empire.

The Deutscher Werkbund is founded in Germany . This organization aims to bring together artists , architects and industrialists to promote the integration of art and industry for the betterment of society and plays a significant role in the development of modern industrial design in Germany.
Edvard Grieg 's Olaf Trygvason , his only opera, is produced posthumously in Christiania, Norway .
Guglielmo Marconi initiates commercial transatlantic radio communications between his high power longwave wireless telegraphy stations in Clifden , Ireland, and Glace Bay, Nova Scotia .
The Hague Convention is revised by the (second) Hague Peace Conference (effective 26 January 1910 ), focussing on naval warfare.

A major United States financial crisis is averted when J. P. Morgan , E. H. Harriman , James Stillman , Henry Clay Frick and other Wall Street financiers create a $25,000,000 pool to invest in the shares on the plunging New York Stock Exchange , ending the bank panic of 1907 .
Černová massacre : Fifteen people are shot during the consecration of a Catholic church in Hungary (modern-day Slovakia ).
The Parliament of Finland approves the Prohibition Act , but the law is not implemented because it is not ratified by Grand Duke Nicholas II .
Russian immigrant bakers Perry and Ben Feigenson in Detroit begin transforming their cake frosting flavors into The Feigenson Brothers Bottling Works soft drink recipe, later shortened to Faygo .
Washington State College defeats the University of Washington 10-5 in the Apple Cup in college football, played in Seattle .
Monongah Mining disaster : A coal mine explosion kills 362 workers in Monongah, West Virginia .
Upon the death of Oscar II , he is succeeded by his son Gustaf V , as king of Sweden .
The largest sailing ship ever built, the 7-masted U.S.-owned Thomas W. Lawson , is wrecked in the Isles of Scilly .
The American Great White Fleet begins its circumnavigation of the world.
Ugyen Wangchuck becomes the first Druk Gyalpo (king of Bhutan ).
An explosion in a coal mine in Jacobs Creek, Pennsylvania kills 239.
Santa María School massacre : In Chile , soldiers fire at striking mineworkers gathered in the Santa María School in Iquique ; over 2,000 are killed.
The first ever " ball drop " is held in Times Square , in New York City .
The British Nimrod Expedition led by Ernest Shackleton sets sail from New Zealand on the Nimrod for Antarctica.
A total solar eclipse is visible in the Pacific Ocean and is the 46th solar eclipse of Solar Saros 130 .
A fire breaks out at the Rhoads Opera House in Boyertown, Pennsylvania , killing 171 people.
Alpha Kappa Alpha , the first race inclusive sorority is founded on the campus of Howard University in Washington, D.C.
Robert Baden-Powell 's Scouting for Boys begins publication in London. The book eventually sells over 100 million copies, and effectively begins the worldwide Boy Scout movement.
Lisbon Regicide : King Carlos I of Portugal and Prince Luis Filipe are shot dead in Lisbon .
Panathinaikos A.O. , a well-known professional multi-sports club of Greece , is founded in Athens .
The first around-the-world car race, the 1908 New York to Paris Race , begins.
Japanese emigration to the United States is forbidden, under terms of the Gentlemen's Agreement of 1907 .
The State Normal and Industrial School for Women, precursor to James Madison University , is founded in Harrisonburg, Virginia .
Football Club Internazionale is founded in Milan , Italy

American diplomat Durham Stevens , an employee of Japan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs , is assassinated in San Francisco by two Korean immigrants , unhappy with his recent support for the increasing Japanese presence in Korea.
The first Scout troop outside the U.K. is formed in Gibraltar .
French aviator Henri Farman makes the world's first flight with a passenger, Léon Delagrange .
H. H. Asquith of the Liberal Party takes office as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom , succeeding Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman .
Sunshine rail disaster : A rear-end collision of two trains in Melbourne , Australia kills 44 people and injures more than 400.
Frederick Cook claims to have reached the North Pole on this date.
October 31 – The Franco-British Exhibition (1908) is held in London.
At Masjed Soleyman in southwest Persia , the first major commercial oil discovery in the Middle East is made. The rights to the resource are quickly acquired by the United Kingdom .
An annular solar eclipse is visible from Central America, North America, Atlantic Ocean and Africa and is the 33rd solar eclipse of Solar Saros 135 .
Kohlerer-Bahn by Bleichert opens in Bolzano , South Tyrol , the first modern aerial enclosed cable car solely for passenger service.
SOS comes into force internationally as a distress signal (originally for ship-to-shore wireless telegraphy ).

Young Turk Revolution in the Ottoman Empire : Major Ahmed Niyazi, with 200 followers (Ottoman troops and civilians), begins an open revolution by defecting from the 3rd Army Corps in Macedonia , decamping into the hill country.
Robert Peary sets sail for the North Pole .
French aviator Léon Delagrange makes the world's first flight with a female passenger, his partner and fellow sculptor Thérèse Peltier .
12 – The steamship Amalthea , housing 80 British strikebreakers in Malmö harbour, Sweden , is bombed by Anton Nilson ; 1 is killed, 20 injured.
The Western University of Pennsylvania is renamed the University of Pittsburgh .

25 – The 1908 Summer Olympics are held in London. (Originally scheduled to be in Rome, but changed due to the Mount Vesuvius eruption of 1906. Figure skating events are held in London from October 28 – 29 .)
Feyenoord , the first Dutch football club to win the UEFA Champions League , is founded at Rotterdam , Netherlands

Young Turk Revolution : The Committee of Union and Progress (CUP) issues a formal ultimatum to Sultan Abdul Hamid II , to restore the constitution of 1876 within the Ottoman Empire ; it is restored the following day.

Italian Dorando Pietri wins the Olympic marathon (run from Windsor Castle to London) in one of the most dramatic arrivals in Olympic history, only to be disqualified soon afterwards for receiving assistance; victory is awarded to Irish-American Johnny Hayes .
The Federal Bureau of Investigation is founded.
28 – The 1908 Hong Kong typhoon sinks the passenger steamer Ying King , causing 421 deaths.
“ Fantasmagorie ”, an animated short film by Émile Cohl , which is widely regarded as the first animated cartoon is officially released.
After an intense power struggle, Sultan Abdelaziz of Morocco is deposed and is succeeded by his brother Abd al-Hafid .
American Messenger Company, predecessor of United Parcel Service , is founded in Washington (state) .
The Great Storm of 1908 starts to pound the Bristol Channel , lasting into the morning of September 2.

The first Minas Geraes -class Dreadnought battleship for Brazil , Minas Geraes is launched at Armstrong Whitworth 's yard on the River Tyne in England, catalysing the " South American dreadnought race ".
At Fort Myer , Virginia , Thomas Selfridge becomes the first person to die in an airplane crash. The pilot, Orville Wright , is severely injured in the crash but recovers.
Classes begin at Benjamin Franklin Institute of Technology in Boston , Massachusetts, established under the terms of Franklin's will.
The Bosnian crisis begins, after the Austro-Hungarian Empire annexes Bosnia and Herzegovina from the Ottoman Empire .
The University of Omaha, precursor of the University of Nebraska Omaha , is founded as a private non-sectarian college.
The Chicago Cubs beat the Detroit Tigers in the 1908 World Series in baseball. The Cubs would not win another World Series for 108 years.
Olivetti , the well-known typewriter and business equipment company, is founded in Italy .
1908 United States presidential election : Republican candidate William Howard Taft defeats William Jennings Bryan , 321 electoral votes to 162.

Western bandits Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid are supposedly killed in Bolivia , after being surrounded by a large group of soldiers. There are many rumors to the contrary however, and their grave sites are unmarked.

King Leopold II of Belgium formally relinquishes his personal control of the Congo Free State (becoming Belgian Congo ) to Belgium, following evidence collected by Roger Casement of maladministration.
Women's suffrage is passed in Victoria , Australia.
Young Emperor Puyi ascends the Chinese throne at age 2.
Construction begins on the RMS Olympic , at the Harland and Wolff Shipyard in Belfast .
A hybrid solar eclipse is visible from Atlantic Ocean and is the 23rd solar eclipse of Solar Saros 140 .
The 7.1 M w Messina earthquake shakes Southern Italy with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI ( Extreme ), killing between 75,000 and 200,000.
Explorer Aeneas Mackintosh of the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition escapes death by fleeing across ice floes .
Colombia recognizes the independence of Panama .

The British Nimrod Expedition to the South Pole , led by Ernest Shackleton , arrives at the farthest south reached by any prior expedition, at 88°23' S, prior to turning back due to diminishing supplies.
The International Joint Commission on US-Canada boundary waters is established.
Members of the Nimrod Expedition claim to have found the magnetic South Pole (but the location recorded may be incorrect).
The White Star Liner RMS Republic sinks the day after a collision with SS Florida off Nantucket . Almost all of the 1,500 passengers are rescued.
The last United States troops leave Cuba , after being there since the Spanish–American War of 1898 .
The Paris Film Congress opens. It is an attempt to create a cartel of leading European producers similar to the MPPC in the United States.
Leo Baekeland announces the creation of bakelite hard thermosetting plastic .
The Anglo-Siamese Treaty of 1909 is signed in Bangkok .
Einar Dessau uses a shortwave radio transmitter in Denmark.
The remains of the Báb are placed in the Baháʼí Shrine of the Báb on Mount Carmel in Haifa , at this time within the Ottoman Empire .
Serbia accepts Austrian control over Bosnia and Herzegovina .
Construction begins on the RMS Titanic , at the Harland and Wolff Shipyard in Belfast .
The association football team Sport Club Internacional is founded in Porto Alegre , Brazil.
Robert Peary , Matthew Henson and four Inuit explorers – Ootah, Ooqueah, Seegloo and Egigingwah – come within a few miles of the North Pole .
The city of Tel Aviv (known in its first year as Ahuzat Bayit ) is founded by the Jewish community, on the outskirts of Jaffa (at this time in the Ottoman Empire).
Adana massacre : Ottoman Turks kill 15,000–30,000 Armenian Christians, in the Adana Vilayet .
Joan of Arc is beatified in Rome.
The Anglo-Persian Oil Company (modern-day BP ) is incorporated.
In Portugal, a magnitude 6.0 earthquake strikes near Lisbon, killing at least 60 people.
Sultan of the Ottoman Empire Abdul Hamid II is overthrown and succeeded by his brother, Mehmed V . He is sent to the Ottoman port city of Thessaloniki (Selanik) the next day.
